urn:contentItem:6FD6-S1G3-RRHJ-N4XB-00000-00Wildfire in New Jersey's Wharton State Forest burns 1,750 acres, 2 campgrounds evacuated2025-03-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisWildfire in New Jersey's Wharton State Forest burns 1,750 acres, 2 campgrounds evacuatedBy Jessica MacAulay, Alexandra Simon, Atheer Hussein, Ryan Hughes(KYW)

Click here for updates on this story

New Jersey (KYW) -- Two New Jersey campgrounds were evacuated as fire crews work to contain a wildfire that broke out in Wharton State Forest in Waterford Saturday afternoon, officials said.

In an update Sunday morning, the New Jersey State Forest Fire Service said the fire, known as the California Branch Wildfire, grew from 1,000 to 1,750 acres overnight. However, the fire is now 50% contained.

The Atsion and Goshen Pond Campgrounds were evacuated Saturday night and remain closed Sunday, though no buildings or homes have had to be evacuated.

The following road closures within the Wharton State Forest also remain in effect:

Raritan AvenueOld Atsion Road5 Mile CrossingGoshen Pond

The NJFFS says another update is expected around 6 p.m. Sunday.

Winds, drought conditions help fuel wildfire

Mike Lupinetti lives in one of the 18 homes that sit near the wildfire, but luckily officials said the flames are moving in the opposite direction.

"It's a little scary because it could jump it could get close," he said. "When I came home from dinner I went out and checked my hoses and made sure I had enough hoses ready just in case."

"Humidity dropped out, wind really kicked up and started being a wind driven wildfire, so at that point, it's hard to catch up to it," said Chief Bill Donnelly, New Jersey Forest Fire Service.

Donnelly said the flames were first spotted by a fire tower around 1:30 pm near Raritan Avenue, but the wildfire likely sparked sometime before dawn Saturday.

Fueled by the winds and dry conditions, Donnelly said this is now the state's fourth major wildfire this year.

"We are coming into a severe drought in portions of Southern New Jersey, we haven't started off a fire season in a severe drought so if we don't get some serious relief, I think our folks out in the field are going to have their hands full," Donnelly said.

Lupinetti told CBS News Philadelphia there have been wildfires near his home before, but this is certainly the closest and the most unnerving.

"Yeah, I'll probably be up a little later tonight than normal just keeping an eye to see if I see any fire," he said.

The NJFFS said crews are constructing and strengthening containment lines while a backfiring operation continues to help contain the fire. An observation helicopter is also on the scene.

The cause of the wildfire is still under investigation.

By Jessica MacAulay, Alexandra Simon, Atheer Hussein, Ryan Hughes

urn:contentItem:6F89-XW33-RS8M-120S-00000-00Early signs of 'quite a fire season' ahead2025-03-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisMARKETPLACEPg. X16Early signs of 'quite a fire season' aheadFrank Kummer (Staff Writer)

New Jersey's wildfire season is off to an ominous start - and it hasn't truly begun.

Already this year, the state has recorded 215 wildfires that have scorched 514 acres. That contrasts with 69 wildfires and 22 acres consumed over the same period in 2024. But wildfire season typically doesn't start until spring, when March winds whip up fires without green vegetation to slow flames.

"That's pretty significant," Bill Donnelly, chief of the New Jersey Forest Fire Service, said Monday. "If things continue the way they are, we're going to have quite a fire season on our hands."

That comes on the heels of last year, which had extreme drought conditions that contributed to one of the worst seasons for fall wildfires many can remember. Those conditions have continued, with the fire danger listed by the Forest Fire Service as high across much of New Jersey over the last week through Tuesday, although heavy rain expected Wednesday should change that.

Most of the southern half of the state is in either a severe or an extreme drought. The counties along the Shore, and the Delaware Bayshore, have fared the worst. Cape May County has endured a rain deficit of more than eight inches over the last year and three inches over the last 90 days.

Surrounding counties are in similar deficits, making conditions morevulnerable to fire when combined with the low humidity and high winds thathave dominated in recent weeks.

"Jan. 1 we started off busy again," Donnelly said. "And here we are, just finishing our second month, and our numbers are astronomical for the amount of fires we've had and the amount of acreage that's burned."

Indeed, last weekend fires broke out in Burlington and Gloucester Counties.

In Salem County, officials say a fire torched about 50 acres in Pennsville. The cause is suspicious and remains under investigation.

In Camden County, firefighters from Gloucester Township and elsewhere contained a 40-acre brush fire that ignited around 9:30 p.m. Saturday near Primrose Lane. More than 100 firefighters and first responders from over 20 state, county, and local agencies were involved. Two homes were evacuated, but none was damaged, and no injuries were reported, police said.

The largest fire, in Hopewell Township, Mercer County, ravaged nearly 300 acres off Poor Farm Road, threatening 30 homes and four businesses before being contained on Sunday. The fire originated from a downed electrical line and rapidly climbed a grass embankment and hill, continuing to spread.

"Typically, 10 miles outside of Trenton you don't see these type of wildfires," Donnelly said. "But when you start to get these temperatures around 60 degrees, and the lower humidity, and wind-driven fires, this is what happens. That was definitely unusual for this time of year."

Greg McLaughlin, the state's administrator for forest and natural lands, said resources are being reallocated from various departments to address fire response needs. The Forest Fire Service operates on an $8 million budget. Gov. Phil Murphy has proposed an additional $1 million for the 2026 fiscal year budget.

McLaughlin emphasized the severity of the situation, stating that with "this excessive and incessant fire frequency and intensity, it's all hands on deck."

In November, Murphy declared a statewide drought warning as rainfall diminished, leading to the eruption of more than 500 wildfires that started in October into November. Water supplies from streams and reservoirs had dramatically declined, and Murphy described conditions at the time as "unprecedented," marking the first drought warning since 2016.

The state remains under a drought warning, prompting the Department of Environmental Protection to urge the public to voluntarily conserve water.

fkummer@inquirer.com

FrankKummer

urn:contentItem:6FP2-N2N3-RXKG-S2SK-00000-00Firefighters hope rain will help, bracing for Sunday winds2025-04-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisU.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES DOCUMENTSFirefighters hope rain will help, bracing for Sunday windsSmith meets firefighters, local officials, residentsRep. Chris Smith (R-NJ) News Release

Rep. Chris Smith (R-NJ) joined firefighters from the New Jersey Forest Fire Service today at the site of the Jones Road Wildfire, which has so far ravaged over 15,000 acres in Southern Ocean County.

"The work of the firefighters has been amazing," Smith said. "These men and women have fought and are continuing to fight until this wildfire is out. They have certainly saved many homes and businesses--and lives--by steering the fire away from populated areas. Still, the fire crossed the Parkway and Route 9 and even reached some bulkheads on Barnegat Bay before it was stopped. The firefighters have worked long and hard, but are absolutely determined."

Smith said firefighters said they were counting on as much rain as possible Saturday to help douse the blaze, which is about 60 percent contained, but were wary of Sunday's expected winds, predicted to be gusts of 40 mph, which threaten to rekindle some areas and keep crews very busy. One firefighter said that on Sunday it would be "all hands on deck."

Smith surveyed areas of the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station, electric high towers, and the Garden State Parkway and Route 9, where the fire skipped over both roads to threaten homes to the east before being stopped at the water's edge of Barnegat Bay just past South Main Street in Lacey Township.

PHOTO: From the left, NJFFS Assistant Division Forest

Firewarden Trevor Raynor shows State Sen. Carmen

Amato and Congressman Chris Smith the charred areas of the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station property. NJFFS Assistant State Forest Firewarden Joe Battersby is at right.

He also stopped at the Liberty Door and Awning business, the only known main structure to be destroyed by the blaze. He consoled and offered assistance to the owner, Bob Nosti. Smith was joined by State Sen. Carmen Amato, Lacey Mayor Pete Curatolo and former Committeeman Mark Dycoff. Only a few blackened support beams remained standing through a pile twisted metal and charred debris. The congressman also met with reporters covering the blaze at the business on Old Shore Road.

Smith noted the Trump Administration quickly okayed a request by the State of New Jersey to be approved to apply for future funding through FEMA's Fire Management Assistance Grant (FMAG). FEMA informed him of the approval Friday. Additionally, he was informed Friday by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that though the plant had been threatened by the blaze at one point, it was now secure.

"The Trump Administration acted quickly so the community can recover, for which I am grateful," Smith said. "In the weeks and months ahead, State, County and local governments can now seek this grant to reimburse the costs of fighting this fire. It will take a full effort by all levels of government to beat this fire and make the communities whole."

SITUATION REPORTS- On Saturday, the most recent reports by the NJFFS stated its crews continue to patrol and monitor key areas and respond to smoke investigations. Smoldering forest materials and burning snags (dead bare trees) are continuing to contribute to hot spots and smokey conditions, and crews are working to mitigate those areas. Low humidity and light southerly winds are expected to blow smoke toward areas north of the wildfire fire area.

Firefighters are working to strengthen their containment of the fire, as well as hold the perimeter while also reducing hotspots. A water drop helicopter will continue to douse priority hotspots near containment lines throughout the day. Crews are closely monitoring areas near the Garden State Parkway and Route 9. More than 20 firefighting vehicles are deployed, such as engine trucks, bulldozers and water tenders.

AIR QUALITY- Smith noted that there are public information resources available to track the fire and any remaining danger to air quality. Concerned residents can make use of these available resources to keep themselves and their families safe, including: the Ocean County's Public Health Advisory with information about health risks associated with smoke; the EPA's AirNow mobile app includes a map showing the status of the fire and smoke (the app can be downloaded here https://www.airnow.gov/airnow-mobile-app/); and the New Jersey Forest Fire Service updates on its Facebook page and X account.

"I am hopeful air quality will improve and be restored as the fire continues to shrink and winds disperse smoke," Smith said.

Additionally, the Ocean County OEM and Red Cross have stated that N-95 masks for any residents who would like one due to poor air quality are available at the Barnegat Township Town Hall lobby at 900 West Bay Avenue, Barnegat, N.J. Additionally, the shelter at Southern Regional High School has been relocated to Saint Mary's Parish Center at 100 Bishop Avenue, Manahawkin, N.J.

urn:contentItem:6FTG-1JH3-RRY1-13M2-00000-00University of Chicago: In Mice, Diet Works Better Than Fecal Transplants to Repair Gut Microbiome2025-05-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisUniversity of Chicago: In Mice, Diet Works Better Than Fecal Transplants to Repair Gut MicrobiomeTargeted News ServiceCHICAGO, Illinois

The University of Chicago issued the following news:

* * *

In mice, diet works better than fecal transplants to repair gut microbiome

By Matt Wood

UChicago study shows microbiome struggles to restore itself on a Western diet after antibiotics

The modern Western-style diet--high in processed foods, red meat, dairy products, and sugar--alters the composition of the gut microbiome in ways that can have a huge impact on health. This dietary pattern, which is also low in fruits, vegetables and whole grains, reduces the variety of microbes in the digestive system and the molecules they produce.

In new research published in Nature, researchers from the University of Chicago show how mice that have been fed a Western-style diet are not able to rebuild a "healthy," diverse gut microbiome following antibiotic treatment. These mice were also more susceptible to infection by pathogens such as Salmonella.

On the other hand, mice given food loosely mimicking a Mediterranean diet--high in plant-based fiber from fruits, vegetables and whole grains--were able to quickly restore a healthy and resilient gut microbiome after antibiotics.

"We were really surprised by how dramatically different the recovery process is in the mice on the Western-style diet versus the healthier one," said Megan Kennedy, a student in the Medical Scientist Training Program at UChicago and lead author of the study.

Rebuilding after a forest fire

Antibiotics can have a devastating effect on the gut microbiome. Though often given to treat infections by specific pathogens, these drugs are indiscriminate. As a side effect, they can wipe out entire communities of bacteria--both the bad ones causing disease and the good, commensal ones that help keep us healthy long-term.

Eugene B. Chang, the Martin Boyer Professor of Medicine at UChicago and a senior author on the study, likens this to a forest fire, suggesting natural rules of ecology apply when rebuilding the community of bacteria in the gut.

"The mammalian gut microbiome is like a forest, and when you damage it, it must have a succession of events that occur in a specific order to restore itself back to its former health," Chang said. "When you are on a Western diet, this does not happen because it doesn't provide the nutrients for the right microbes at the right time to recover."

"Instead, you end up with a few species that monopolize these resources and don't set the stage for other organisms that are required for recovery," he said.

Antibiotics and highly processed foods are both common in the U.S., which led Kennedy and Chang to explore how this combination of microbiome-disrupting practices affects gut health.

They started with mice that were fed with food mimicking a typical modern diet or a "mouse chow" with diverse sources of plant fiber and low fat. Both groups were then treated with antibiotics. Later, some mice continued the same diet, while others were switched to the different diet.

The researchers also reintroduced microbes to the mice after antibiotics through fecal microbial transplants. The rationale behind using these transplants is that it can restore a healthy equilibrium in the gut by transferring microbes in the stool from one healthy animal to another.

When the researchers analyzed the makeup of microbes in these different test groups, they saw that only the mice on the plant fiber-rich diet, either before or after antibiotics, were able to recover to a healthy equilibrium of microbes. Further analysis by Christopher Henry, a computational biologist at Argonne National Laboratory, and his group showed that this diet promotes networks of metabolites that set the stage for microbes to rebuild a healthy ecosystem.

In contrast, fecal microbial transplants had a negligible impact on recovery among the mice on Western diets after antibiotics. These mice were also susceptible to infection with Salmonella, a common intestinal pathogen.

"It doesn't seem to matter what microbes you're putting into the community through a fecal microbial transplant, even if it's matched in every way possible to the ideal transplant," Kennedy said. "If the mice are on the wrong diet, the microbes don't stick, the community doesn't diversify and it doesn't recover."

Eat your fruit and vegetables, again

Kennedy and Chang say this shows how diet builds the crucial foundation for a diverse, robust and resilient gut microbiome.

Besides promoting overall good health, one potential clinical application is using diet to treat infections in patients following cancer treatment or organ transplants. These patients are often placed on powerful antibiotics and immunosuppressant drugs, which can lead to infections with multidrug-resistant bacteria.

Adding more antibiotics would only compound the situation.

"Maybe we can [instead] use diet to rebuild the commensal microbes that have been suppressed under these therapies," Chang said. "We can restore the healthy microbiome much quicker and prevent the emergence of more multidrug-resistant organisms."

Despite the new details on how diet changes the gut microbiome, the study also repeats the same message parents have been telling their kids since time immemorial: Eat your fruits and vegetables, they're good for you.

But both researchers also recognize they can't expect everyone to become vegans overnight for the sake of their health.

Kennedy suggests that people could think about adding more healthy foods to their diet to prepare for an upcoming surgery when they know they'll be taking antibiotics. Chang is also working on what he calls a "have your cake and eat it too" approach, where people could take custom supplements to bolster their gut health, even if they don't drastically change their diet.

"I've become a believer that food can be medicinal," Chang said. "In fact, I think that food can be prescriptive, because we can ultimately decide what food components are affecting which populations and functions of the gut microbiome."

The other senior author on the paper is Joy Bergelson, formerly of UChicago, now Silver Professor of Biology at New York University and executive vice president of life sciences at the Simons Foundation.

Citation: "Diet outperforms microbial transplant to drive microbiome recovery in mice," Kennedy et al, Nature, April 30, 2025.

Funding: National Institutes of Health, Gastrointestinal Research Foundation of Chicago, Simons Foundation, U.S. Department of Energy; collaborators at the Chinese University of Hong Kong were funded by the Innovation and Technology Council of Hong Kong.

- Adapted from an article first published by the Biological Sciences Division.

SECTION 2 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

2.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

September 02: Weyerhaeuser Concludes Sale of Princeton Lumber Mill to Gorman Group

Weyerhaeuser Company has completed the sale of its lumber mill in Princeton, British Columbia, to the Gorman Group. This transaction, initially announced in May, includes the transfer of Weyerhaeuser's associated timber licenses in British Columbia, which are expected to be finalized in the coming months, subject to regulatory review and customary closing conditions.

As part of the sale, Weyerhaeuser received approximately $60 million USD upfront, with additional proceeds tied to the transfer of the timber licenses. The company has recognized a gain from the sale but anticipates a tax liability of about $11 million USD as a result of the transaction. This sale reflects Weyerhaeuser's ongoing strategy to optimize its operations and focus on its core business areas.

Established in 1900, Weyerhaeuser is among the largest private owners of timberlands worldwide, managing approximately 10.4 million acres in the U.S. and additional public timberlands in Canada. The company is recognized for its commitment to sustainability, operating all its timberlands in compliance with internationally recognized forestry standards. In 2024, Weyerhaeuser reported net sales of $7.1 billion and employed around 9,400 people globally.

The Gorman Group, a family-owned business founded in 1951, operates multiple divisions in Southern British Columbia and northern Washington state, employing about 900 individuals. The company is well-regarded for its high-value lumber products, particularly in the home finishing and renovation markets. The acquisition of Weyerhaeuser's mill aligns with Gorman Group's long-term strategy of enhancing its operational capabilities and market presence.

Weyerhaeuser's decision to divest its Princeton mill is part of a broader trend in the timber industry, where companies are reassessing their portfolios to focus on areas with higher growth potential.

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

ECONOMIC AND MARKET CONDITIONS AFFECTING OUR OPERATIONS

Our market conditions and the strength of the broader U.S. economy are, and will continue to be, influenced by the trajectory of activity in the U.S. housing and repair and remodel segments, inflation trends and interest rates. The demand for sawlogs within our Timberlands segment is directly affected by domestic production of wood-based building products. The strength of the U.S. housing market, particularly new residential construction, strongly affects demand in our Wood Products segment, as does repair and remodeling activity. Seasonal weather patterns impact the level of construction activity in the U.S., which in turn affects demand for our logs and wood products. Our Timberlands segment, specifically the Western region, is also affected by export demand and trade policy. Japanese housing starts are a key driver of export log demand in Japan. The demand for pulpwood from our Timberlands segment is directly affected by the production of pulp, paper and oriented strand board (OSB), as well as the demand for biofuels, such as wood-burning pellets made from pulpwood. Our Timberlands segment is also influenced by the availability of harvestable timber. SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

<p><strong>Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity</strong></p>

<p>Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.</p>

<p><strong>Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program</strong></p>

<p>Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.</p>

<p><strong>Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges</strong></p>

<p>Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.</p>

<p><strong>Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility</strong></p>

<p>The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.</p>

<p><strong>Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing</strong></p>

<p>Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.</p>

<p><strong>Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency</strong></p>

<p>Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.</p>

<p><strong>Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth</strong></p>

<p>Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.</p>

<p><strong>Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures</strong></p>

<p>The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.</p>

<p><strong>Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base</strong></p>

<p>Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.</p>

<p><strong>Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures</strong></p>

<p>Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.</p>

<p><strong>Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities</strong></p>

<p>Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.</p>

<p><strong>Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness</strong></p>

<p>Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.</p>

urn:contentItem:6FP9-4HD3-RRW1-D1BK-00000-00A wildfire closes main highway linking Tel Aviv to Jerusalem and sends 12 people to the hospital2025-04-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSA wildfire closes main highway linking Tel Aviv to Jerusalem and sends 12 people to the hospitalIBRAHIM HAZBOUN and ELENA BECATOROSAssociated PressJERUSALEM

JERUSALEM — A wildfire shut the main highway linking Tel Aviv to Jerusalem on Wednesday, sending at least a dozen people to the hospital and turning skies over Jerusalem gray.

Video footage showed vehicles stranded nearby as flames spread throughout the area, while another video showed the fire approaching a Catholic monastery.

The fire was being whipped up by strong winds and hot, dry weather. The cause was being investigated. Help was on the way from across the region, including aircraft from Italy, Croatia and North Macedonia, Israeli officials said.

Helicopters were dropping water to battle the flames from above, while other firefighting teams were responding on ATVs.

“We hope to reach 150 firefighting teams,” Israel's National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir said.

The fire occurred as Israel observes Memorial Day for fallen soldiers and victims of attacks, ahead of Independence Day on Thursday. Many of the planned events were being canceled, including the official national ceremony in Jerusalem. The event had been set for Mount Herzl, near the fire zone. Instead, a recording of the dress rehearsal was being broadcast.

Those taken for hospital treatment mostly suffered from smoke inhalation, while another 10 people were treated in the field, Magen David Adom Ambulance services said. Residents living close to the fire zone were evacuated, police said.

Officials at the monastery, the Latin Patriarchate of Jerusalem, said it was too early to assess the damage, if any. The religious communities had been safely evacuated, they said.

“We pray for the safety of everyone,” their statement said.

As flames advanced towards the Tel Aviv-to-Jerusalem highway, many people abandoned their cars and fled on foot or hitched rides with other vehicles heading in the opposite direction.

In 2010, a massive forest fire burned for four days on northern Israel’s Mount Carmel, claiming 44 lives and destroying around 12,000 acres, much of it woodland.

urn:contentItem:6GMW-9R43-RY13-804W-00000-00Damage quantification of mining explosion-proof equipment using thermal flame dynamics and improved LSTM2025-11-15T08:03:50Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisDamage quantification of mining explosion-proof equipment using thermal flame dynamics and improved LSTM

Publisher’s noteSpringer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.

Abstract

To address the lack of quantitative characterization methods for flame propagation during internal non-ignition detonation tests of explosion-proof equipment, this study proposes a damage severity quantification method using an improved LSTM model with thermal imaging feature fusion. A detonation flame thermal imaging dataset is constructed, where flame contours are segmented and features extracted via a pre-trained Faster R-CNN. Temporal sampling generates flame image sequences, from which key spatiotemporal features—area, centroid velocity, aspect ratio, circularity, and area change rate—are derived to describe dynamic flame propagation. Based on this, the improved LSTM captures time-varying behavior: a first-layer bidirectional LSTM fuses forward and backward temporal data to detect propagation direction changes, multi-layer stacking extracts high-level features for adapting to damage scale variation, and Dropout between layers mitigates overfitting. Experimental results show prediction errors remain within 2% across 5–20 cm damage levels. The near-zero shift in error distribution confirms the effectiveness of bidirectional fusion, deep feature modeling, and regularization in capturing flame temporal dynamics. This research provides a data-driven approach for accurate damage diagnosis and supports safety certification and maintenance of mining explosion-proof equipment, with implications for coal mine safety.

IntroductionThe explosion-proof performance of coal mining equipment is a critical prerequisite for safe production. Currently, coal mine explosion-proof equipment must pass the internal non-ignition detonation test (where devices are placed in sealed containers filled with explosive gas and ignited to determine flame containment) to obtain underground operation licenses. This method relies solely on pressure sensors to measure post-explosion pressure changes inside equipment, resulting in inefficient and low-precision assessments that yield only binary “pass/fail” outcomes1,2. With the advancement of intelligent mining processes, integrated coal mine equipment has increased in complexity and size3, amplifying inspection challenges and costs. Critically, existing methods cannot quantify surface crack severity induced by non-transmission explosion tests. When varying degrees of surface cracks occur during these tests, they trigger corresponding transient combustion phenomena. Traditional detection methods fail to capture flame characteristics or accurately assess potential equipment damage during detonation propagation, rendering current inspection protocols ineffective.

For the problems of complex experimental environments with poor lighting conditions and instantaneous changes in flame detonation propagation processes, traditional detection methods struggle to capture transient flame characteristics. Majid4 and Huang5 respectively proposed an attention-optimized EfficientNetB0 model and a color-guided anchoring strategy improved Faster R-CNN, which enhance flame detection accuracy (95.4% accuracy rate) and efficiency through transfer learning and masked convolution, but both rely on static images in open environments and fail to resolve the spatiotemporal feature coupling problem of underground transient flames; Zhang6 integrated ResNet50 with feature pyramid networks (FPN) to enhance multi-scale feature representation capability, achieving 5.7% accuracy improvement in small-target fire detection, while still failing to overcome complex background dynamic interference limitations. Currently, the primary detection method for mining equipment still relies on pressure sensors to assess equipment damage. Sarwar7 and Khatir8 respectively optimized damage assessment robustness by fusing multi-source sensor data through probabilistic deep neural networks and artificial neural networks, but their models did not consider the multiphysics coupling effects of underground explosion shockwaves and dust.

The deficiencies of traditional detection methods are reflected in two aspects: Firstly, existing methods only focus on equipment qualification determination, ignoring the impact of dynamic parameters such as flame propagation speed and intensity on damage extent. Su9 constructed blast resistance evaluation models based on p-I curves to quantify structural damage thresholds, but excluded dynamic flame propagation parameters; Wang10 utilized 69,000 flame images to train AI models for non-contact heat release rate (HRR) real-time prediction, but did not establish spatiotemporal correlations between HRR and equipment damage severity. Secondly, existing detection methods rely on single sensors, making it difficult to simultaneously consider flame morphology and temperature field multidimensional information. Pei11, Ni12, and Yao13 respectively improved temperature field measurement dimensions through multi-spectral imaging, single thermal imagers, and acoustic thermometry technology, but 2D thermal maps or static calibration processes cannot resolve underground flame 3D dynamic morphology; Bhatti14, Liu15, and Guo16 proposed multi-feature fusion models based on 3D-CNN, graph attention networks (GAT), and dual-path downsampling, achieving 97.45% accuracy in spatial-spectral classification tasks, but their static data input was not adapted to underground flame temporal evolution and multi-physics interference; Sun17 balanced noise suppression and detail retention through wavelet transforms and dual attention mechanisms, Ma18 developed low-light enhancement networks to optimize underground image quality, but their models still require improvement in explosion highlight suppression and multi-modal data fusion; Wang19 developed multi-spectral thermal imaging systems to capture transient temperature fields, but equipment costs and underground adaptability constrained multi-damage-level feature extraction. Among existing deep learning methods, Yu20, Lv21, and Zhou22 respectively enhanced temporal feature modeling through improved Mask R-CNN, CNN-LSTM, and self-attention mechanisms, but cross-dimensional correlation analysis of flame propagation paths remains insufficient. Zhang23 revealed flame momentum-buoyancy transition threshold effects through burner experiments, providing theoretical basis for dynamic parameter analysis, but their idealized models excluded explosion shockwaves and dust interference.

Existing research methods typically struggle to achieve effective quantitative assessment of damage in mining explosion-proof equipment. To address this challenge, this study proposes a quantitative diagnostic model based on thermal imaging features; however, conventional thermal analysis methods are limited by insufficient multi-dimensional feature coupling resolution and inadequate dynamic spatiotemporal feature modeling. To overcome these limitations, we develop a spatiotemporal feature-enhanced Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) diagnostic framework for quantitatively determining damage severity in mining explosion-proof equipment. Unlike traditional pressure sensors that only provide pass/fail assessments, our method achieves breakthrough quantitative evaluation of breach sizes (5–20 cm range) by analyzing flame dynamic characteristics during internal detonation tests—such as flame flashback phenomena caused by switch contact damage—through a framework integrating Faster R-CNN for real-time flame recognition, fusing multi-dimensional thermal features, and employing an improved LSTM architecture for deep spatiotemporal modeling. This integrated approach significantly enhances flame propagation dynamics characterization, ultimately enabling high-precision quantitative diagnosis of equipment damage levels.

Quantitative damage mechanism for detonation testing of explosion-proof equipment based on thermal imaging information

This study proposes an improved LSTM model that integrates spatiotemporal thermal imaging features generated during internal non-ignition detonation tests of mining explosion-proof equipment, aiming at the quantitative analysis of surface cracks. The central mechanism is that equipment damage alters the dynamic characteristics of internal detonation flames, leading to sudden variations in flame area, fluctuations in centroid velocity, and anomalies in morphological parameters such as aspect ratio and circularity. These changes reflect the severity of structural cracks and provide measurable evidence of damage progression.

Physically, larger or deeper cracks allow more flame to leak through the damaged surface, resulting in a rapid increase in flame area and higher centroid velocity as the hot gases escape at greater intensity. As crack severity increases, the flame also tends to become more stable and regular in its boundary, which is manifested as higher circularity. Conversely, smaller cracks restrict gas ejection, producing irregular and unstable flame shapes with lower circularity and fluctuating propagation speed. These relationships establish a clear physical link between flame morphology and the extent of damage, which can be effectively captured and quantified through thermal imaging.

To model these processes, flame image sequences under different damage levels are acquired using infrared thermal imagers. A pre-trained Faster R-CNN model automatically identifies flame regions and extracts key features including area, centroid velocity, aspect ratio, and circularity, which are further processed into time-series data using sliding averaging techniques. This dataset serves as the basis for quantitative analysis.Subsequently, a bidirectional stacked LSTM network is designed to capture the temporal evolution of flame features. Its first bidirectional layer simultaneously models forward and reverse dependencies in flame propagation, while the second LSTM layer extracts higher-order spatiotemporal features. Dropout regularization between layers suppresses overfitting, and early stopping dynamically optimizes the training process. The model outputs a standardized damage severity score ranging from 0 to 1. After post-processing with sliding weighted averaging, a high-precision quantitative diagnosis of damage severity is achieved, providing a reliable basis for explosion-proof equipment safety assessment.

Fig. 1

Overall Scheme of Equipment Damage Diagnosis Method.

Detonation test flame thermal map feature analysis

Flame static characteristics

An internal non-ignition detonation tests of mining explosion-proof equipment, non-compliant equipment generates detonation flames. Due to the strong randomness and irregularity of flame combustion regions, flame areas require automatic recognition and extraction through object detection technology. This study employs a pre-trained Faster R-CNN model to detect flames, representing detected flame regions in the form of bounding boxes. Subsequently, a series of geometric and morphological calculations are performed on these bounding boxes to form flame static feature vectors. Core steps are shown below:

Bounding Box Analysis.

And the aspect ratio is:3

The centroid of the flame region can be approximated as the center point of the bounding box and undergoes normalization, so that centroid coordinates distribute within . Its expression is:4

These centroid coordinates can be used to calculate temporal features of flames such as moving velocity and direction.

Circularity.

To better characterize morphological differences in flame boundaries, this paper calculates the flame perimeter () using approximate rectangular contours, thus obtaining circularity.5

where is the flame perimeter calculated by Euclidean distance summation of contour verticesWhen the flame shape is closer to a circle, this value is larger; when the flame shape is irregular, this value is relatively smaller. Perimeter (). Obtained by cumulative summation of Euclidean distances between contour vertices. If the perimeter is too small, outlier processing is required.

Through the above methods, flame static characteristics such as area, aspect ratio, centroid coordinates, and circularity in each frame can be obtained, forming the basis for flame detection and geometric description.

Flame temporal features

Due to the intense and instantaneous evolution of flames during detonation propagation, static features of single-frame images cannot fully reflect the dynamic changes of flames in the time dimension. By this, after extracting static features, flame temporal features are further constructed including area change rate, centroid moving velocity, and sliding averaging, aiming to characterize flame evolution patterns from the time dimension.

Area Change Rate.

Denote the area of the flame at frame () as (), then the difference between it and the previous frame’s flame area is:6

If the previous frame’s area is not zero, the area change rate () can be defined as:7

To reflect instantaneous growth or contraction situations of flame area.

Centroid Moving Velocity.

Treating flame centroid coordinates as discrete-time positions, setting the interval between adjacent frames as:8

Sliding Mean.

Considering the significant short-term fluctuations in flame regions, sliding mean (Moving Average) processing is introduced for key indicators such as area and circularity to smooth noise. For the sequence , define the sliding window average with length (k) as:9

Mean processing reduces the impact caused by accidental fluctuations and can better capture the overall trend of flame evolution.

Through the above steps, multi-dimensional temporal features (including area change rate, centroid moving velocity, and sliding mean features) are obtained, and although nine spatiotemporal features were initially extracted, PCA and feature importance ranking confirmed flame area, centroid velocity, and circularity contribute > 85% variance dominance while other features enhance robustness – hence retaining the full feature set to balance accuracy and stability, which comprehensively reflects flame dynamics beyond static detection and supports crack diagnosis models.

Improved LSTM network time-sequential characteristic modeling

The LSTM network is a commonly used recurrent neural network primarily employed for modeling sequential data. Its fundamental unit controls information flow through input, forget, and output gates, enabling effective memorization of long-term dependencies. Conventional networks typically adopt single-layer or multi-layer stacked LSTM structures that directly input multidimensional feature sequences extracted from flame images, outputting damage severity predictions after LSTM processing. This model’s input feature dimensions directly inherit Sect. 2 outputs: each timestep contains 6-dimensional static features (width, height, area, aspect ratio, Centroid Coordinates, Circularity) and 3-dimensional temporal features (area change rate, centroid moving velocity, sliding mean), constituting a 9-dimensional feature vector.

In practical experiments, the original unidirectional LSTM network encounters limitations when processing detonation flame data due to rapid dynamic flame changes and strong bidirectional dependencies: Unidirectional LSTM can only capture information before the current time step, ignoring the impact of future information on the current state; this easily causes loss of temporal information when predicting damage severity. Secondly, networks with single-layer or simple stacking structures possess limited deep feature abstraction capabilities, being unable to fully capture subtle changes in flame image features such as minor fluctuations in flame area, centroid velocity, etc. Thirdly, due to noise and abrupt changes in the data, the original network tends to overfit during training, thereby compromising the model’s generalization performance on new samples.

To address this issue, an improved LSTM network suitable for internal non-ignition detonation tests is proposed. The algorithmic structure specifically includes three improvements: First, adding a bidirectional processing layer after the input layer to capture full-time dependencies of flame propagation by simultaneously processing forward and reverse sequences; Second, adopting a deep stacking architecture where two LSTM units are connected after the bidirectional layer output, and specially inserting Dropout (0.3) operations between layers to enhance anti-noise capability; Finally, adding Dropout (0.1) at the feature input end to further suppress data mutation interference. The architecture of the proposed improved algorithm is presented in Fig. 2(a), while Fig. 2(b) details the fundamental LSTM unit:

Fig. 2

Algorithm Structure Diagram Based on Improved LSTM.

The overall workflow of the improved algorithm is shown in Fig. 3: Original flame feature data undergoes preprocessing including completeness checks and missing value removal, then enters the model training phase through standardization and time-window generation. After feature learning in the improved LSTM network, damage prediction values of equipment are finally outputted through testing set prediction and inverse standardization, and visual analysis results are provided.

Fig. 3

Improve LSTM network process.

Improved LSTM network as follows:

(1) In traditional LSTM, the hidden state at each timestep () depends solely on historical information, . However, the morphology of detonation flames correlates not only with the past but also with future flame change trends. To address this, a bidirectional LSTM (Bi-LSTM) is introduced in the first layer. Its forward hidden state is denoted , backward hidden state is denoted , then for input sequence there is:

​10

The final output hidden state concatenates forward and backward orientations:11

Under scenarios of intense flame feature fluctuations or abrupt short-term changes, Bi-LSTM can simultaneously utilize information from both past and future to enhance the judgment accuracy of flame morphology at the current timestep.

(2) To enhance the high-order representation capability for flame temporal features, a second LSTM layer is added after the bidirectional LSTM. Denote the output sequence of the first layer as , denote the second LSTM layer as , and its hidden state as :12

Where is the hidden state of the second LSTM layer at timestep . Differing from the first layer, only the hidden state at the final timestep is taken as the comprehensive representation of the entire flame sequence, achieving deep abstraction of multiple flame features evolving over time. Compared with single-layer or shallow structures, multi-layer stacking progressively refines high-order correlations between features such as flame area, centroid velocity, circularity within the network, helping to more accurately judge damage severity.

(3) Flame images often contain substantial noise and unstable factors. Without proper regularization measures, the network easily overfits, leading to poor prediction performance on new data. This paper adds Dropout layers both between the bidirectional LSTM and the second LSTM layer, and after the second LSTM layer output, making them randomly drop 30% and 10% of neuron outputs respectively. Taking the first Dropout layer as an example, if its input is , the output is denoted :13

Where represents element-wise multiplication, is a random mask vector with the same shape as . Each element has a probability of being set to zero. By randomly masking part of neurons during training, the model’s excessive dependence on single features or local noise is suppressed, significantly enhancing the network’s generalization capability. Since detonation flame data often exhibit abrupt changes, Dropout effectively reduces the model’s “memory bias” in regions of intense local fluctuations while improving learning efficacy for overall trends.

(4) The gating mechanism of LSTM includes input gate , forget gate , output gate , and candidate state . Their typical formulas are as follows:14

Where in flame time-sequential data, due to possible sudden increases or decreases in flame area, if improperly initialized during early training, the forget gate and input gate of traditional LSTM can easily lead to untimely adaptation to abrupt information. For this reason, the forget gate bias is initialized as a positive number, so that the network tends to retain past information in the initial phase, avoiding premature forgetting before fully learning flame temporal patterns. Meanwhile, the input gate bias is initialized slightly less than 0, making the model cautious about new information during initial training, only “opening” the input gate when sufficient evidence exists and significantly updating the cell state.

(5) After undergoing Dropout processing again on the hidden state at the final timestep of the second LSTM layer, is obtained. This tensor serves as the deep representation of the entire flame time-sequential feature sequence, which is then fed into the fully connected layer to output the final damage severity prediction value with a linear activation function:15

Where and are learnable weights and biases. Since the damage severity of mining explosion-proof equipment is considered a continuous variable in this experiment, the network output also adopts linear activation to directly regress numerical damage severity.

In the experimental phase, when the model performs inference on test set flame time-sequential features, the network outputs corresponding to true damage severity labels. To quantify prediction effectiveness, Mean Squared Error () and Coefficient of Determination () are adopted to evaluate the difference between and true values :16

Where is the number of test samples, is the true damage severity of the i-th sample is the model predicted value, is the average value of true damage severity. reflects the average magnitude of prediction errors, while measures the model’s explanatory power for damage severity fluctuations. To validate the diagnostic capability of the model for damage extent of mining explosion-proof equipment, a multi-damage-level flame propagation experimental platform is constructed. The trained model is applied to test samples under different damage levels, comparing the differences between and to evaluate the network’s learning effectiveness for flame spatiotemporal evolution patterns.

Experimental result analysis

Dataset and experimental setup

A dataset was constructed from multi-dimensional temporal features extracted from flame videos, comprising 7,445 samples spanning four damage sizes: 5 cm (n = 1,489), 10 cm (n = 1,902), 15 cm (n = 2,471), and 20 cm (n = 1,583). Data preprocessing, standardization, and sliding window segmentation partitioned the dataset into training, validation, and test subsets.

Baseline and enhanced LSTM networks were trained and evaluated on identical processed data to ensure experimental parity. The configuration (Fig. 4) utilized rectangular cracks with fixed 2 cm width and progressive lengths (5–20 cm) to simulate contact damage morphology, achieving equivalent area coverage through controlled occlusion. Representative samples appear in Fig. 5, with thermal imager specifications documented in Table 1.

All models implemented Adam optimization (initial learning rate = 0.001, batch size = 32) with early termination after 10 validation-loss plateaus within 50-epoch maxima. Spatiotemporal feature extraction employed a pre-trained Faster R-CNN model, attaining 99.83% mAP@0.5(IoU threshold = 0.5) on the detection dataset, thereby enabling reliable sequential modeling inputs.

Based on partial damage crack flame characteristic data presented in Table 2, a systematic evolution pattern of flames can be clearly observed as damage value increases from 5 cm to 20 cm: Flame area and area change rate synchronously expand significantly, while centroid velocity (centroid velocity refers to the speed of centroid in normalized coordinates) rapidly rises between 5 and 10 cm and stabilizes in the 15–20 cm range. Regarding morphological features, aspect ratio continuously increases, indicating flame development shifts from vertical to horizontal spread; circularity steadily rises, reflecting an overall trend of improved flame edge regularity and enhanced combustion stability.

Ablation experiment

To validate the effectiveness of improvements made for damage severity prediction of mining explosion-proof equipment in flame spatiotemporal feature modeling, a multi-modal feature fusion ablation experiment was designed. Five model variants were constructed and trained/tested under identical dataset conditions. The designs of each model are as follows:

Table 3

Ablation experimental results.

ModelMSEMAERMSEModel A (Base LSTM)0.00120.01430.03480.9989Model B (Base LSTM + Dropout)0.00180.02740.04200.9984Model C (Single-layer bidirectional LSTM + Dropout)0.00280.02880.05320.9975Model D (Stacked LSTM + Dropout)0.00080.01640.02770.9993Model E (Improved LSTM, Two-layer bidirectional + Dropout)0.00070.01290.02580.9994

As seen from Table 3, Improved LSTM (Model E) leads other models with the lowest value of 0.0007, followed by Stacked LSTM (Model D, 0.0008). Base LSTM (Model A) has an MSE of 0.0012, while Model B with direct dropout addition to a single layer and Model C with bidirectional dropout show MSE increases to 0.0018 and 0.0028 respectively, indicating that introducing over-strong regularization in shallow networks loses partial critical information. This phenomenon may stem from the limited feature extraction capability of shallow LSTM itself: While suppressing overfitting, the dropout layer excessively weakens the network’s modeling capability for flame time-sequential dynamics, resulting in effective feature loss.

On the R²metric, Model E achieves 0.9994, exhibiting the best fitting effect; Model D also has a high R² of 0.9993; Model A is 0.9989, while Model B and Model C decrease to 0.9984 and 0.9975 respectively, reconfirming the limitations of the single-layer dropout strategy in this task.

Regarding Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Model E performs best with the lowest value of 0.0129, exhibiting minimal prediction deviation per sample; Model D’s MAE is 0.0164, also better than Base LSTM’s 0.0143. In contrast, MAE of Model B and Model C reaches as high as 0.0274 and 0.0288 respectively, with large fluctuations. This indicates that under single-layer structure, random neuron deactivation of Dropout exacerbates prediction instability of the model, especially during abrupt changes in flame propagation velocity or low-illumination noise interference, where prediction deviation increases significantly. Meanwhile, Model E achieves stable control of sample-level deviation through synergistic effects of deep feature abstraction in the two-layer bidirectional LSTM and Dropout, suppressing overfitting while retaining critical temporal patterns.

The RMSE metric similarly validates this trend: Model E is only 0.0258, suppressing extreme deviations in prediction error; Model D and Model A have RMSE of 0.0277 and 0.0348 respectively, while Model B/Model C’s RMSE rises to 0.0420 and 0.0532 respectively. Since RMSE is sensitive to outliers, the low value of Model E indicates significantly reduced variance in its predictions. This benefits from bidirectional structure’s joint modeling of forward-backward dependencies in flame propagation and stacked layers’ hierarchical extraction of multi-scale temporal features, thereby reducing overfitting to local noise.

To analyze prediction error distribution across models, MAE/MSE error bar comparison charts are shown in Fig. 6.

Fig. 6

MAE/MSE error histogram.

Figure 6 shows MAE/MSE error bar comparisons across different models (including std). In Fig. 6 (a), Model E (two-layer bidirectional LSTM + Dropout) has the shortest error bar and shortest error line, indicating its minimal sample-level deviation; error bars and error lines in Fig. 6 (b) also reconfirm Model E’s minimum overall error. For Model B with Dropout directly added to single-layer LSTM, MAE and MSE are as high as 0.0274 and 0.0018 respectively, with longer error lines. This demonstrates that excessive regularization in shallow networks causes critical information loss and significantly reduced prediction accuracy.

Through ablation experiment comparative analysis, among the five models designed in this paper, Model E (two-layer bidirectional LSTM + Dropout) achieves optimal performance across all metrics: Its MSE is only 0.0007, R²reaches 0.9994, MAE and RMSE are 0.0129 and 0.0258 respectively, demonstrating extremely low prediction errors and the best fitting effect; while Model D (Stacked LSTM + Dropout) also exhibits high precision and stability. In contrast, Model B with direct Dropout addition to single-layer LSTM shows significantly increased MSE and MAE, indicating that excessive regularization in shallow networks causes critical information loss and impairs prediction accuracy. The overall results prove that effective integration of multi-layer stacking and bidirectional structure, along with moderate regularization strategies, significantly enhances modeling capability for flame time-sequential features, providing strong support for precision quantitative prediction of damage severity in mining explosion-proof equipment.

Different algorithms prediction performance comprehensive comparison

To comprehensively evaluate the performance of different temporal models in damage severity prediction tasks for mining explosion-proof equipment, five architectures were considered: Base LSTM, Improved LSTM (two-layer bidirectional + Dropout), CNN-LSTM, GRU, and Transformer. Evaluation metric results of each model on the test set are summarized in Table 4.

Table 4

Prediction results of different algorithms.

ModelMSEMAERMSEBase LSTM0.00110.99900.01640.0329CNN-LSTM0.00070.99940.01920.0255GRU0.00190.99830.02900.0432Transformer0.00260.99770.03160.0512Improved LSTM0.00040.99960.01180.0209

The CNN-LSTM model employs Conv1D layers to extract local temporal features, reduces temporal dimensions via MaxPooling1D, and finally feeds the processed sequence into LSTM layers for global temporal modeling. This architecture effectively captures local variation patterns, but its capacity for comprehensive temporal information modeling remains constrained by convolutional kernels’ limited receptive fields. Meanwhile, GRU—as a streamlined LSTM variant—achieves higher computational efficiency through reduced parameters and simplified gating mechanisms, yet demonstrates inferior capability in capturing complex flame dynamics and long-term dependencies.

In comparison, the Transformer model leverages multi-head self-attention to establish global dependencies across flame feature sequences. Although theoretically ideal for long-range sequence modeling, However, experimental results indicate that the Transformer underperforms on this task with an overall MSE of 0.002619, MAE of 0.03157, RMSE of 0.05118, and R² of 0.9977. This evidence indicates that while Transformers excel in modeling extended sequences, they exhibit reduced robustness compared to recurrent architectures when processing relatively short, noisy sequences derived from flame dynamics. Additionally, the Transformer displays significantly greater prediction variability across damage levels, demonstrating notable sensitivity to dataset size and environmental noise.

By contrast, the Improved LSTM model, leveraging its bidirectional information capture and multi-layer stacking structure, effectively enhances the expressive capacity for complex dynamics in flame temporal data. The incorporation of layer-wise Dropout reduces overfitting risk, ultimately achieving the highest prediction accuracy and stability among all tested models. Specifically, its overall MSE is 0.0004, R² reaches 0.9996, and MAE and RMSE are 0.0118 and 0.0209 respectively, significantly outperforming other models. Basic LSTM and CNN-LSTM also demonstrate competitive accuracy, though inferior to the improved architecture in global temporal feature extraction and error suppression. In contrast, GRU and Transformer exhibit relatively poorer stability and higher prediction error, confirming that effective integration of bidirectional recurrence and moderate regularization remains more suitable for modeling detonation flame temporal patterns under the current experimental conditions.

To more intuitively demonstrate prediction effects, Fig. 7 shows MAE/MSE line chart comparisons across damage levels, while Fig. 8 presents box plots of absolute error distributions. As shown in Fig. 7, the Improved LSTM consistently achieves the lowest error curves with minimal fluctuations. Base LSTM and CNN-LSTM follow with slightly higher but stable errors. GRU and Transformer display the largest error variations, with the Transformer curve oscillating significantly across damage levels. In Fig. 8, the error box of Improved LSTM is the most compact with the lowest median, indicating stable and accurate predictions; Base LSTM and CNN-LSTM exhibit moderate dispersion; GRU and Transformer show wider boxes with more outliers, signifying greater instability in prediction:

Fig. 7

MAE/MSE error line comparison chart.

Fig. 8

Box diagram of absolute error of each model.

Through comparative analysis, the results demonstrate that among the tested models, the Improved LSTM achieves the best balance of accuracy and robustness. Other models, including Base LSTM, CNN-LSTM, GRU, and Transformer, also show certain predictive capabilities but remain less competitive in capturing complex spatiotemporal dynamics of flame evolution. Overall, the results confirm that the bidirectional multi-layer LSTM with Dropout provides the most effective and stable framework for quantitative damage severity prediction in detonation testing.

Conclusion

Addressing the issue that existing explosion-proof equipment detonation tests lack fine-grained quantitative analysis of flame propagation processes and cannot accurately assess potential damage to equipment caused by flame propagation processes, this paper proposes a spatiotemporal feature-enhanced LSTM-based damage severity diagnostic method for mining explosion-proof equipment. Through extensive comparative experiments on simulated coal mine explosion-proof test data, the following conclusions are reached:

Addressing the defect that traditional pressure sensing methods cannot resolve spatiotemporal characteristics of flame propagation, a bidirectional stacked LSTM architecture is designed, integrating multidimensional dynamic features such as flame velocity. The improved LSTM model’s Mean Squared Error (MSE = 0.0007) was reduced by 41.7% compared to Base LSTM (MSE = 0.0012), verifying the analytical capability of bidirectional temporal modelling for flame dynamic propagation-damage correlation relationships.

To enhance the modeling of bidirectional dependencies in flame evolution, the temporal backbone is deepened to a two-layer bidirectional LSTM. As a result, the Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) decreases from 0.0532 (single-layer bidirectional LSTM) to 0.0258, a 51.5% reduction, indicating that deeper bidirectional recurrence effectively suppresses extreme deviations.

Regarding regularization, compared with the uniformly regularized shallow variant (Base LSTM + Dropout), the improved model exhibits a 52.9% lower MAE (0.0129 vs. 0.0274) and a 38.6% lower RMSE (0.0258 vs. 0.0420), showing that appropriate regularization in a deeper recurrent architecture enhances robustness while preserving key temporal features.

While rectangular cracks were used to simulate damage in this study, future work will validate the model on irregular damage patterns (e.g., radial cracks from impact tests) and integrate online prediction latency tests, enhancing generalizability and real-time deployment feasibility in field scenarios.

Experimental results indicate that the improved model outperforms all baseline models across four metrics: MSE (0.0007), MAE (0.0129), RMSE (0.0258), and Coefficient of Determination (R²=0.9994). Its bidirectional stacked structure reduces prediction error variance (MSE) by up to 75%, significantly enhancing the robustness of damage level determination. This study’s method provides high-precision (R²≥0.999), low-fluctuation (RMSE ≤ 0.026) quantitative diagnostic tools for the safety assessment of mining explosion-proof equipment, and its multi-scale temporal modelling framework offers theoretical and experimental foundations for subsequent model optimization and multi-model fusion in more complex environments.

urn:contentItem:6FTG-VCY3-RSWR-V04M-00000-00IN MICE, DIET WORKS BETTER THAN FECAL TRANSPLANTS TO REPAIR GUT MICROBIOME2025-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisIN MICE, DIET WORKS BETTER THAN FECAL TRANSPLANTS TO REPAIR GUT MICROBIOMEStates News ServiceCHICAGO, Illinois

The following information was released by the University of Chicago:

By Matt Wood

UChicago study shows microbiome struggles to restore itself on a Western diet after antibiotics

The modern Western-style diethigh in processed foods, red meat, dairy products, and sugaralters the composition of the gut microbiome in ways that can have a huge impact on health. This dietary pattern, which is also low in fruits, vegetables and whole grains, reduces the variety of microbes in the digestive system and the molecules they produce.

In new research published in Nature, researchers from the University of Chicago show how mice that have been fed a Western-style diet are not able to rebuild a "healthy," diverse gut microbiome following antibiotic treatment. These mice were also more susceptible to infection by pathogens such as Salmonella.

On the other hand, mice given food loosely mimicking a Mediterranean diethigh in plant-based fiber from fruits, vegetables and whole grainswere able to quickly restore a healthy and resilient gut microbiome after antibiotics.

"We were really surprised by how dramatically different the recovery process is in the mice on the Western-style diet versus the healthier one," said Megan Kennedy, a student in the Medical Scientist Training Program at UChicago and lead author of the study.

Rebuilding after a forest fire

Antibiotics can have a devastating effect on the gut microbiome. Though often given to treat infections by specific pathogens, these drugs are indiscriminate. As a side effect, they can wipe out entire communities of bacteriaboth the bad ones causing disease and the good, commensal ones that help keep us healthy long-term.

Eugene B. Chang, the Martin Boyer Professor of Medicine at UChicago and a senior author on the study, likens this to a forest fire, suggesting natural rules of ecology apply when rebuilding the community of bacteria in the gut.

"The mammalian gut microbiome is like a forest, and when you damage it, it must have a succession of events that occur in a specific order to restore itself back to its former health," Chang said. "When you are on a Western diet, this does not happen because it doesn't provide the nutrients for the right microbes at the right time to recover."

"Instead, you end up with a few species that monopolize these resources and don't set the stage for other organisms that are required for recovery," he said.

Antibiotics and highly processed foods are both common in the U.S., which led Kennedy and Chang to explore how this combination of microbiome-disrupting practices affects gut health.

They started with mice that were fed with food mimicking a typical modern diet or a "mouse chow" with diverse sources of plant fiber and low fat. Both groups were then treated with antibiotics. Later, some mice continued the same diet, while others were switched to the different diet.

The researchers also reintroduced microbes to the mice after antibiotics through fecal microbial transplants. The rationale behind using these transplants is that it can restore a healthy equilibrium in the gut by transferring microbes in the stool from one healthy animal to another.

When the researchers analyzed the makeup of microbes in these different test groups, they saw that only the mice on the plant fiber-rich diet, either before or after antibiotics, were able to recover to a healthy equilibrium of microbes. Further analysis by Christopher Henry, a computational biologist at Argonne National Laboratory, and his group showed that this diet promotes networks of metabolites that set the stage for microbes to rebuild a healthy ecosystem.

In contrast, fecal microbial transplants had a negligible impact on recovery among the mice on Western diets after antibiotics. These mice were also susceptible to infection with Salmonella, a common intestinal pathogen.

"It doesn't seem to matter what microbes you're putting into the community through a fecal microbial transplant, even if it's matched in every way possible to the ideal transplant," Kennedy said. "If the mice are on the wrong diet, the microbes don't stick, the community doesn't diversify and it doesn't recover."

Eat your fruit and vegetables, again

Kennedy and Chang say this shows how diet builds the crucial foundation for a diverse, robust and resilient gut microbiome.

Besides promoting overall good health, one potential clinical application is using diet to treat infections in patients following cancer treatment or organ transplants. These patients are often placed on powerful antibiotics and immunosuppressant drugs, which can lead to infections with multidrug-resistant bacteria.

Adding more antibiotics would only compound the situation.

"Maybe we can [instead] use diet to rebuild the commensal microbes that have been suppressed under these therapies," Chang said. "We can restore the healthy microbiome much quicker and prevent the emergence of more multidrug-resistant organisms."

Despite the new details on how diet changes the gut microbiome, the study also repeats the same message parents have been telling their kids since time immemorial: Eat your fruits and vegetables, they're good for you.

But both researchers also recognize they can't expect everyone to become vegans overnight for the sake of their health.

Kennedy suggests that people could think about adding more healthy foods to their diet to prepare for an upcoming surgery when they know they'll be taking antibiotics. Chang is also working on what he calls a "have your cake and eat it too" approach, where people could take custom supplements to bolster their gut health, even if they don't drastically change their diet.

"I've become a believer that food can be medicinal," Chang said. "In fact, I think that food can be prescriptive, because we can ultimately decide what food components are affecting which populations and functions of the gut microbiome."

The other senior author on the paper is Joy Bergelson, formerly of UChicago, now Silver Professor of Biology at New York University and executive vice president of life sciences at the Simons Foundation.

Citation: "Diet outperforms microbial transplant to drive microbiome recovery in mice," Kennedy et al,Nature, April 30, 2025.

Funding: National Institutes of Health, Gastrointestinal Research Foundation of Chicago, Simons Foundation, U.S. Department of Energy; collaborators at the Chinese University of Hong Kong were funded by the Innovation and Technology Council of Hong Kong.

Adapted from an article first published by the Biological Sciences Division.
