urn:contentItem:6FXX-CKW3-RS3D-M2BY-00000-00Canadian wildfires smoke to pour into North Dakota this weekend2025-05-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisAPg. 001Canadian wildfires smoke to pour into North Dakota this weekendBLAKE NICHOLSON Bismarck Tribune

Smoky skies and potentially unhealthy air are forecast to return to North Dakota this weekend, as wildfires once again rage across Canada.

The Canadian province of Manitoba, part of which borders North Dakota, has declared a state of emergency due to nearly two dozen wildfires that have forced the evacuations of nearly 17,000 people across several communities, according to The Associated Press. Manitoba Premier Wab Kinew is sending in military to help.

“This is the largest evacuation Manitoba will have seen in most peoples' living memory,” he said.

There also are fires in Saskatchewan -- which also borders North Dakota -- and all the way west in Canada to British Columbia, according to AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Alex Sosnowski. Saskatchewan Public Safety Agency Vice President of Operations Steve Roberts said "Many of the fires were started by human activity, such as debris burning near cabins, carelessness with ATVs and UTVs in dry grass, picnics and firepits placed in dry areas, and general inattention to fire conditions."

More than 1,500 wildfires so far this summer have burned a total of more than 2 million acres north of the border, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. As of Friday there were about 175 active fires, including nearly 100 that were considered "out of control." Many of those were in Manitoba and Saskatchewan.

Smoke is forecast to drift south over the Northern Plains and Midwest beginning late Friday and lasting at least through the weekend, and it could linger into next week. The weekend smoke in North Dakota is likely to be close to the surface, impacting visibility at ground level, according to the National Weather Service's Bismarck office.

The Weather Service's weekend forecast for North Dakota calls for mostly sunny skies and warm daytime temperatures in the 70s and 80s.

"Most of these areas in the Midwest will have days where there is little or no rain around and the sun is out over the weekend. So the smoke will be more noticeable," AccuWeather Senior Meteorologist Adam Douty said.

Wildfire smoke has been an on-and-off issue in North Dakota the past several summers. It is particularly dangerous because it contains tiny particulate matter, the tiniest of pollutants. When inhaled, it can move deep into lung tissue and enter the bloodstream. It has been linked to several health complications including asthma, heart disease and other respiratory illnesses.

The North Dakota Department of Environmental Quality is urging residents to monitor the Air Quality Index to protect their health -- especially those with respiratory conditions, older adults, young children and other sensitive groups.

Health impacts can vary depending on air quality and individual health status, according to DEQ. Sensitive people might experience symptoms even when air quality levels are considered “moderate.” If air quality reaches the “unhealthy for sensitive groups” or “unhealthy” categories, people should considering taking precautions including limiting or avoiding outdoor activity, staying indoors with windows and doors closed, and setting air conditioners and vehicle vents to recirculate indoor air, the agency said.

Information on wildfires and air quality is on the state Department of Environmental Quality website, at bit.ly/3OhrD7E. The federal Environmental Protection Agency’s map of fire and smoke conditions is at https://fire.airnow.gov/. The AirNow mobile phone app, and many other weather apps, also include air quality information. Wildfire smoke pattern predictions can be found at https://firesmoke.ca/forecasts/current/.

AirNow is a partnership of federal and state agencies including the EPA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

SECTION 2 CORPORATE PROFILE AND INDEPENDENT RATINGS

2.1 Activities

Weyerhaeuser Company, headquartered in Seattle, Washington, is one of the largest private owners of timberlands in the world, with a history dating back to 1900. Its core business activities center on sustainable forest management, timber harvesting, and the production of wood products. The company''s largest sources of revenue come from its Timberlands segment, which includes the sale of logs and timber, and its Wood Products segment, which manufactures and distributes lumber, engineered wood, and other building materials primarily for residential and commercial construction. Additionally, Weyerhaeuser operates a Real Estate, Energy, and Natural Resources segment, focusing on land sales and renewable energy opportunities. Among its business lines, the Wood Products segment has shown notable growth, driven by strong demand in the housing and construction markets. With a commitment to environmental stewardship, Weyerhaeuser continues to balance profitability with sustainable practices across its extensive land holdings. It is the NYSE's 5th largest Building materials & fixtures company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2024, the top earner of Revenue was WOOD PRODUCTS [68%] followed by TIMBERLANDS [26.9%] at Rank 2 and REAL ESTATE & ENR [5.1%] at Rank 3. In FY 2024, revenue growth was highest in REAL ESTATE & ENR [7.7%] .

May 28: Weyerhaeuser, Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance Partner for Fourth Year to Provide Mental Health Resources for Wildland Firefighters

Fighting Fires Together campaign raises awareness and helps address mental health challenges of wildland firefighting

SEATTLE, May 28, 2025- Weyerhaeuser Company (NYSE: WY) and Firefighter Behavioral Health Alliance (FBHA) today announced an extension of their Fighting Fires Together campaign, a partnership that provides specialized mental health support for wildland firefighters and their families across the Pacific Northwest.

Fighting Fires Together, now in its fourth year, addresses the often-overlooked mental health impacts of wildland firefighting in isolated, hazardous and highly stressful conditions. Through a free online resource hub, first responders can find specially designed content, including videos about Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety and suicide prevention, along with mental health tips, educational articles and contacts for occupationally aware support groups and counselors in Oregon, Washington and British Columbia.

Weyerhaeuser's support for wildland firefighting efforts in the Pacific Northwest began in the aftermath of the Yacolt Burn in 1902, when the company began advocating for Washington's first forest fire legislation and the funding of community fire prevention education and patrols. Today, as Weyerhaeuser celebrates its 125th anniversary, the company continues to play an active role in fire prevention and response through its forest management operations. Weyerhaeuser employees and contractors receive annual fire readiness training, build fire breaks and containment lines, conduct aerial surveys and deploy tanker trucks, helicopters and quick-response crews to wildland fires.

"After launching the Fighting Fires Together campaign with FBHA four years ago, we're proud to continue this effort to support wildland firefighters and their mental health as they work in challenging conditions to protect our communities," says Bill Frings, vice president of Western Timberlands for Weyerhaeuser.

SECTION 5 WEYERHAEUSER 10-Q: 12 CONSEQUENTIAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS

<p><strong>Strategic Expansion of Engineered Wood Products Capacity</strong></p>

<p>Management has committed $500 million to constructing a new TimberStrand facility in Monticello, Arkansas, beginning in 2025, with operations expected by 2027. This investment is projected to expand engineered wood products capacity by 10 million cubic feet, positioning Weyerhaeuser to seize greater market share in the growing housing sector. While the long-term growth and revenue potential align with favorable housing trends, the funding approach-whether via existing cash or external financing-could pressure short-term liquidity or increase debt levels.</p>

<p><strong>Shareholder Value Enhancement Through New $1 Billion Buyback Program</strong></p>

<p>Following completion of a prior program, management authorized a new $1 billion share repurchase initiative in May 2025. This move underscores confidence in company valuation and enhances earnings per share by reducing outstanding shares. While the initiative aligns with the shareholder return framework targeting 75-80% of Adjusted FAD, it reflects a strategic trade-off by potentially limiting capital allocation flexibility during potential market volatility.</p>

<p><strong>Maintaining Dividend Stability Amid Economic Challenges</strong></p>

<p>Weyerhaeuser continues its cash dividend framework, targeting a 75-80% payout of Adjusted FAD, and has paid $304 million in 2025 dividends thus far. The year-to-date payout decline-due primarily to an absence of supplemental dividends in Q1-highlights the company's adaptability to fluctuating cash flows. For income-focused investors, this consistent dividend policy provides predictability, though variability in Adjusted FAD may influence future distributions.</p>

<p><strong>Strengthened Liquidity with an Updated Credit Facility</strong></p>

<p>The company amended and restated its revolving credit facility in June 2025, increasing capacity to $1.75 billion and extending maturity to 2030. This ensures access to substantial liquidity without current borrowings, providing operational flexibility while reducing refinancing risks during economic uncertainty. The alignment of covenant compliance further supports Weyerhaeuser's credit profile.</p>

<p><strong>Capital Optimization through Debt Repayment and Refinancing</strong></p>

<p>Management refinanced maturing debt by repaying $210 million in debentures while issuing a $300 million senior unsecured term loan maturing in 2030. This strategic action reduced the weighted average interest rate, trimming interest expense by $2 million year-to-date, while preserving $592 million in cash and full credit availability. For investors, this showcases disciplined capital allocation, though possible fluctuations in interest rates remain a key consideration.</p>

<p><strong>Focused Capital Investments to Drive Operational Efficiency</strong></p>

<p>Excluding the Monticello project, management outlined $400 million in planned 2025 capital expenditures, with $200 million deployed so far. This includes both Timberland and Wood Products maintenance expansions designed to sustain production efficiency. Despite a year-over-year increase, such investments affirm a long-term strategy to sharpen competitiveness-though revenue pressure could strain cash flow in adverse market conditions.</p>

<p><strong>Expansion into Carbon Markets to Capture Sustainability Growth</strong></p>

<p>Weyerhaeuser progresses in leveraging its natural climate solutions, capitalizing on the growing demand for carbon credits and renewable energy. By positioning itself within key sustainability sectors, management aims to unlock new revenue streams while aligning with global decarbonization goals. Though regulatory adjustments and market development require monitoring, this initiative offers potential upside for forward-looking investors.</p>

<p><strong>Unlocking Value Through Strategic Divestitures</strong></p>

<p>The announced sale of a wood products manufacturing facility (pending regulatory approvals) reflects Weyerhaeuser's strategy to streamline operations and optimize its asset base. If successful, this move could free up cash for reinvestment in higher-margin opportunities and improve overall profitability. However, pending closures introduce timing uncertainties for short-term financial performance.</p>

<p><strong>Timberland Acquisition to Strengthen Strategic Resource Base</strong></p>

<p>Management advanced a timberland acquisition that remains subject to regulatory approval. This investment supports long-term timber supply needs for the Timberlands segment while positioning the company in tightening log markets. The targeted synergies enhance revenue potential, though integration risks and upfront costs require careful oversight.</p>

<p><strong>Operational Efficiency Improvements Amid Inflationary Pressures</strong></p>

<p>Initiatives to restructure manufacturing processes and reduce costs address inflation-driven challenges related to raw materials, energy, and labor. By improving cost structures, Weyerhaeuser aims to mitigate margin compression and enhance profitability. Successful implementation will be key, especially given labor market constraints influencing production continuity.</p>

<p><strong>Proactive Risk Management for Contingent Liabilities</strong></p>

<p>Reserves for litigation and environmental responsibilities demonstrate management's financial diligence in safeguarding against operational uncertainties. By maintaining adequate coverage for contingent liabilities, Weyerhaeuser bolsters its balance sheet resilience. However, potential over-reserving may tie up capital unnecessarily and requires vigilant management assessment.</p>

<p><strong>Prioritizing Workforce Stability Amid Labor Market Tightness</strong></p>

<p>Recognizing a 4.1% unemployment rate as a constraint, Weyerhaeuser focused on hiring and talent retention across its segments. Stability in workforce availability ensures operational continuity and supports management's strategic initiatives. However, rising labor costs remain a potential margin-pressure risk-a critical area to monitor for sustained profitability.</p>

April 22nd, 2025 (BNO News — Delivered by Newstex)

A fast-moving wildfire burning through Ocean County, New Jersey has prompted the evacuation of more than 3,000 residents and is threatening over 1,300 structures, according to fire officials.

Dubbed the Jones Road Wildfire, the blaze has scorched approximately 3,200 acres and was only 5% contained as of 8:10 p.m. Tuesday. The fire is burning in wooded areas east of Philadelphia and southeast of Trenton, with heavy flames reported dangerously close to homes and businesses.

Mandatory evacuations began earlier Tuesday afternoon for 16 buildings on Wells Mills Road, between Bryant Road and the Garden State Parkway, in Ocean Township. By 6 p.m., authorities expanded the evacuations to include the Route 9 area in Lacey Township, according to New Jersey 101.5. As of 8 p.m., a total of 1,320 structures were under evacuation orders.

Several shelters have been established for displaced residents, including at Southern Regional High School, which is also accommodating pets.

Road closures remain in effect across a wide area, including: Route 532 (Wells Mills Road) between Route 72 and the Garden State Parkway, Bryant Road between Route 532 and Route 539, Jones Road between Route 532 and Bryant Road, a stretch of the Garden State Parkway between Barnegat Road and Lacey Road and portions of Route 9 and various secondary and local roadways.

Videos shared on social media show flames dangerously close to structures, with fire engines and emergency services on scene.

The New Jersey Forest Fire Service has deployed multiple resources to fight the fire, including bulldozers, ground crews, and fire engines. Numerous local fire, rescue, and law enforcement agencies are assisting. No injuries have been reported.

urn:contentItem:6FWD-RD03-RRYR-G1BS-00000-00Fire tax increases sought in five of seven districts2025-05-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisSTATE AND REGIONAL NEWSFire tax increases sought in five of seven districtsNANCY MCCLEARYThe Sanford Herald, N.C.

Lee County’s fire departments are facing challenges brought about by increases in operating costs, equipment replacement and a continuing lack of volunteers willing to serve.

The fire departments are looking to find money to help fund the needs, sometimes using reserve funds and upping taxes in their respective districts.

“Volunteerism throughout our state continues to decrease. The fire departments in Lee County are taking steps to mitigate these issues with paid staff, assuring there will always be someone to answer the call for service,” John Rzycki, chair of the Lee County Fire Advisory Board, told county commissioners at their Monday meeting.

Each department presents its proposed budget to the Fire Advisory Board, which then makes funding recommendations. The Lee County commissioners will consider the requests in their proposed 2025-26 budget.

Five departments are asking to raise fire district taxes to address shortages and a lack of manpower. They are Tramway, Cape Fear, Northview, Lemon Springs and Carolina Trace fire departments.

Residents living in the Pocket and Deep River districts will not see an increase in the tax rate.

Tramway is seeking an increase of $138,972 in their 2025-26 budget, an increase of 19.9%, according to Rzycki. The district’s tax base grew by $26.7 million.

The advisory board recommends the requested increase while raising the district tax to 10.7 cents, a 2.5-cent increase from the previous year.

The Cape Fear department’s request has increased by $109,564 or 13.4%, Rzycki said. The budget calls for $43,000 for an increase in personnel costs and $9,000 increase for its capital budget and debt funding.

Cape Fear is contracted to provide service to the Clearwater Forest Fire Department. The Cape Fear tax base increased by $78.6 million, while the Clearwater tax base grew by $1.2 million.

The combined total of the two districts is $710,862,997. With $40,000 from the fund balance, the proposed tax rate is 14.4 cents, up 1.7 cents from last year.

Northview is seeking to increase the district tax from 9 to 9.4 cents, but the department has had decreases in its budget in the prior years. That includes a reduction in the cost of retirement and health insurance for full-time staff and using a part-time staff instead.

The district’s tax base decreased by $4.9 million. With that reduction and the use of $40,000 from it fund balance, the rate would increase slightly.

The Lemon Springs Department is increasing its request by 17.7% to $100,600 to cover a cost-of-living raise and more man-hours. A proposed increase of 2.5 cents would raise the tax rate to 10.7 cents.

The Carolina Trace department is seeking a 15.3% increase in its funding request of $125,112. The rise is the result of an increase in salaries, providing 12-hour shifts during the day and night for 24-hour coverage. The department’s tax base grew by $25.8 million. With the request and $25,000 in fund balance money, the department is seeking to raise its tax rate from 12.8 cents to 14.1 cents.

urn:contentItem:6FJ8-6FX3-RRT2-72F7-00000-00CM Punk On Returning To WWE After Saying He Wouldn't: 'LIfe Teaches You Lessons'2025-04-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisCM Punk On Returning To WWE After Saying He Wouldn't: 'LIfe Teaches You Lessons'

Jeremy Thomas

April 11th, 2025 ( 411mania.com - Delivered by Newstex )

CM Punk didn't ever expect to return to WWE until he did return, and he recently talked about that decision in a new interview. The WWE star spoke on The Rich Eisen Show about making his return to WWE in November of 2023 after his AEW exit, noting that the company's 'shake up' with Vince McMahon exiting the company was a big factor.

'I obviously, famously said that I'm never coming back,' Punk said (per Wrestling Inc). 'Never. And what does life do to you? Well, life humbles you. Life teaches you lessons. Life tells you, you never say never. I can confidently say that if it was the same place that it was, with the same people in charge, yeah, I don't think either side would have really reached out. It never would have happened.'

He continued, 'But amidst a shake-up of the hierarchy of the company, [it was] the right place, right time. Timing is everything in life and in sports, and it came to fruition. You know, it starts with an idea, it starts with that little spark, that little match, and it turns into a pretty big forest fire.'

Punk is set to face Seth Rollins and Roman Reigns in a triple threat match to main event WrestleMania 41 night one.

urn:contentItem:6CKW-KKF1-JDKC-R0FY-00000-00US Patent Issued to ALCHERAX on July 30 for "Forest fire detection system and method capable of determining whether events are same" (South Korean Inventors)2024-07-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisUS Patent Issued to ALCHERAX on July 30 for "Forest fire detection system and method capable of determining whether events are same" (South Korean Inventors)ALEXANDRIA, Va.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 31 -- United States Patent no. 12,051,311, issued on July 30, was assigned to ALCHERAX INC. (Sunnyvale, Calif.).

"Forest fire detection system and method capable of determining whether events are same" was invented by Hee Chan Park (Ansan-si, South Korea), Minkook Cho (Seoul, South Korea), Jae Hyeok Kang (Seongnam-si, South Korea), Youngseo Cha (Yongin-si, South Korea) and Yewon Jun (Seoul, South Korea). According to the abstract* released by the U.S. Patent & Trademark Office: "Provided are a forest fire detection system and method capable of determining whether events. The forest fire detection system includes an artificial intelligence-based forest fire detection module configured to detect a forest fire from a captured image using an artificial intelligence model; a monitoring camera configured to monitor a predetermined area; a direction estimation module configured to estimate a direction of the forest fire on a map, using a plurality of forest fire detection images provided from the artificial intelligence-based forest fire detection module and data of the monitoring camera; and a same event determination module configured to determine whether events represented by the plurality of forest fire detection images are the same, based on the estimated direction of the forest fire." The patent was filed on Sept. 13, 2022, under Application No. 17/943,349. *For further information, including images, charts and tables, please visit:

urn:contentItem:6FNW-GMV3-RTB1-M1FH-00000-00New Jersey's Jones Road Wildfire Now 65% Contained2025-04-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisNew Jersey's Jones Road Wildfire Now 65% Contained

The New Jersey Forest Fire Service has continued to make progress fighting the Jones River wildfire. The service reported the fire was 65% contained by Sunday morning April 27.

However, the service repeated a warning from the National Weather Service that there is an increased risk for rapid fire spread across portions of southern New Jersey due to low humidity values and northwest winds 15 to 20 mph with 30 to 40 mph gusts. "These conditions, along with the continued drying of fine fuels, could support the rapid spread of any fires that ignite, which could quickly become difficult to control," the service warned.

The fire had burned 15,300 acres as of Sunday morning.

No injuries have been reported. About four structures remain under threat. One commercial building has been destroyed and multiple outbuildings and vehicles have been damaged

The fire started on April 22 and has spread throughout the southern Ocean County area.

Update on New Jersey Wildfire: Suspect Charged With Arson

New Jersey officials announced last Wednesday that a 19-year old man has been charged with arson in connection with the wildfire. Joseph Kling of Waretown failed to properly extinguish a bonfire of wooden pallets, according to state and county officials. They said an investigation revealed that Kling set wooden pallets on fire - and then left the area without the fire being fully extinguished.

According to officials, Kling was taken into custody and then transported to the Ocean County jail, where he is awaiting a detention hearing.

Like all defendants, Kling is presumed innocent unless and until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt in a court of law.

Forecast Calls for Wildfires to Burn More Land Across US This Year

A new report by AccuWeather says that abnormally dry conditions and warm weather could boost the fire danger along the Eastern Seaboard through the rest of this spring. The spring fire risk on the East Coast extends as far south as parts of southern Florida, according to the forecast.

Top Photo: Firefighters battle a wildfire in Lacey Townships, N.J. on Tuesday, April 22, 2025. (New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection via AP)

urn:contentItem:6FSW-8S43-RWCT-D1YF-00000-00New Study Findings from Universiti Malaya Illuminate Research in Forestry (Multilevel Peatland Governance: Exploring the Policy Impact among Local Actors in Shaping Peatland Policy Intervention in Indonesia)2025-05-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisLIFE SCIENCES - FORESTRYNew Study Findings from Universiti Malaya Illuminate Research in Forestry (Multilevel Peatland Governance: Exploring the Policy Impact among Local Actors in Shaping Peatland Policy Intervention in Indonesia)


2025 MAY 12 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- Investigators publish new report on forestry. According to news reporting originating from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Indonesia established the Peatland Restoration Agency (BRG, now BRGM) in 2016 to address land and forest fire issues through measures to develop and strengthen the implementation of policies to restore some part of the 24 million hectares of the country's damaged peatlands."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Universiti Malaya: "BRGM was presented as a response to the transboundary haze issue and was applauded globally, with substantial success claimed in delivering changes in local land management behaviours. However, limited detailed analyses have been conducted regarding how the BRGM programme is implemented. Employing concepts drawn from work exploring multilevel governance strategies and actor-network theory (ANT), we explore how the BRGM's programmes were implemented in seven different district locations in Riau province. We focus on local actors' views concerning the programme to assess local perceptions and responses to BRGM initiatives. Our findings show that multilevel peatland governance, as implemented by BRGM, encounters significant obstacles and challenges. Key issues were linked to poor coordination and synergy between different levels of governance and the actors involved, which in turn hampered collaboration efforts."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "In addition, problematic implementation due to formal and informal power struggles linked to actors' diverse interests also inevitably impacted local responses to the programme and, hence, its performance and efficacy. We suggest that these underreported factors inevitably affect the BRGM programmes' capacity to deliver on their formal aims sustainably and may hinder the achievement of justice and equity outcomes in the community."
For more information on this research see: Multilevel Peatland Governance: Exploring the Policy Impact among Local Actors in Shaping Peatland Policy Intervention in Indonesia. Forest and Society, 2025,9(1). (Forest and Society - http://journal.unhas.ac.id/index.php/fs). The publisher for Forest and Society is Hasanuddin University.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.24259/fs.v9i1.36612.
Our news editors report that more information may be obtained by contacting Alfajri Alfajri, Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences, Universiti Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Additional authors for this research include Helena Varkkey, Patrick O'Reilly, Tengku Adeline Adura. Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world. urn:contentItem:6FNV-F2T3-S5RX-61BP-00000-00ON THE JONES ROAD WILDFIRE AND THE FIREFIGHTERS' HEROIC RESPONSE2025-04-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisON THE JONES ROAD WILDFIRE AND THE FIREFIGHTERS' HEROIC RESPONSE

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Rep. Chris Smith issued the following news:

Rep. Chris Smith (R-NJ) today issued the following statement on the Jones Road Wildfire and the heroic response by firefighters:

"I want to express my deep and sincere gratitude to the expert men and women who have been working under extraordinary conditions to fight back against and contain the Jones Road Wildfire which has been raging in parts of my congressional district in Ocean County.

Thankfully, no one has suffered life-threatening injuries-despite the fact that over 12,500 acres of forest have burned in what may turn out to be New Jersey's largest forest fire in 20 years.

"It takes very special, courageous people to battle wildfires day and night to save complete strangers and entire communities. As a long-time member of the Congressional Fire Services Caucus, I remain deeply impressed and forever grateful for the hard work and the sacrifices our firefighters made to protect all of us.

There are public information resources available to track the fire and any remaining danger to air quality. Concerned residents can make use of these available resources to keep themselves and their families safe.

For more information, please see the resources below.

(1) Ocean County's Public Health Advisory for the Jones Road Wildfire and information about health risks associated with smoke can be found here;

(2) The EPA's AirNow mobile app includes a map showing the status of the fire and smoke. The app can be downloaded here; and

(3) The New Jersey Forest Service plans to offer further updates on its Facebook page and X account.

Additionally, the Ocean County OEM and Red Cross have stated that N-95 masks for any residents who would like one due to poor air quality are available at the Barnegat Township Town Hall lobby at 900 West Bay Avenue, Barnegat, N.J. Additionally, the shelter at Southern Regional High School has been relocated to Saint Mary's Parish Center at 100 Bishop Avenue, Manahawkin, N.J. urn:contentItem:6FXN-7YY3-RX81-J25K-00000-00Heavy smoke expected to hit the US as dangerous Canadian wildfires force 17K to evacuate2025-05-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Heavy smoke expected to hit the US as dangerous Canadian wildfires force 17K to evacuateMichael Loria

USA TODAY

Show Caption Hide Caption 'Massive smoke plumes' from wildfires cover Canadian provincesTimelapse satellite imagery shows wildfires and thick smoke over two Canadian provinces on Monday, May 26. CSU/CIRA & NOAA via StoryfulCSU/CIRA & NOAA As many as 17,000 people in Canada are being evacuated as active wildfires have charred hundreds of thousands of acres in the country, officials said, threatening to waft heavy smoke over the northern United States. Rising heat, winds, and dry air sparked blazes in the Canadian provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba, according to the country's Department of Natural Resources. Residents in the United States are expected to face poor air quality from the fires as soon as May 30.  "This is a very serious situation," Saskatchewan Premier Scott Moe said at a news conference on May 29. "I do fear things are going to deteriorate with the weather we have ahead of us in the days ahead." Active blazes have burned 696,000 acres in Saskatchewan and 173,000 acres in Manitoba, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. A total of nearly 1.5 million acres have burned across the two provinces so far this year, according to the fire center. Moe said he expected the fires to worsen until a two or three-day rainfall event. Smoke from the blazes is expected to fall heavily over Midwestern states, including Wisconsin, Minnesota, and Michigan, and cut across the country to reach the Carolinas by May 31, according to FireSmoke Canada, a team of forecasters at the University of British Columbia. Canadian authorities have called in the military to help with the "sheer scale" of the evacuations, Manitoba Premier Wab Kinew said at a news conference.  "We're talking about hours instead of days to move this amount of people," said Kinew, adding it was the largest evacuation "seen in most people's living memory."  The two provinces have declared a state of emergency. The blazes also stretch into the province of Ontario, where 130,000 acres have burned. Canadian wildfires, again The smoke drifting over the United States from the Canadian blazes comes after American cities in the Northeast, Midwest, and Plains encountered unhealthy air quality due to the nightmarish wildfires in Canada in 2023. Over 6,000 blazes left more than 37 million acres burned, an area larger than England, according to Canada's natural resources department.  The American Lung Association's 2025 "State of the Air Report" found that a growing number of Americans were living with poor air quality due to the Canadian fires, even as other means of pollution were reduced. The report was based on data through 2023. As of May 29, 1,500 blazes have charred 1.8 million acres across Canada. 'We were not prepared': Canada fought nightmarish wildfires as smoke became US problem What to expect in the United States Smoke from the blazes is expected to waft over large parts of the United States starting in the Midwest, according to forecasters at FireSmoke Canada. Minnesota began feeling the impact of the blazes on May 29, according to the state's Pollution Control Agency. Upper Wisconsin and the Upper Peninsula of Michigan were expected to experience poor air quality by the evening. Smoke is expected to hit the Ohio Valley on May 30 and the Carolinas by the early hours of Saturday. Minnesota authorities warned of unhealthy levels of exposure to fine particles from the wildfires. Symptoms include everything from shortness of breath to heart attack and stroke.

urn:contentItem:6G01-2583-RT40-G09M-00000-00Canadian wildfire smoke is back again. How bad will it get?2025-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Canadian wildfire smoke is back again. How bad will it get?

USA TODAY

Show Caption Hide Caption EPA issues air quality warnings due to Canada firesIn the U.S., smoke from Canadian wildfires was detected drifting through Montana, North Dakota and northern Minnesota. In June 2023, a surreal glowing orange haze descended on New York City and across other East Coast locations as winds concentrated and redirected smoke from Canada wildfires. The smoke eventually lessened, but continued causing widespread unhealthy air quality in the United States throughout the spring and summer. There are signs that this summer could bring a similar problem, as June 2025 brings hazy skies and air quality concerns in some areas. The bad news: Smoke will likely be an ongoing health hazard across North America for the next few months. "Communities across both Canada and the United States should stay informed about air quality advisories and be prepared for potential health impacts related to smoke exposure," atmospheric scientist Djordje Romanic of McGill University told USA TODAY in an e-mail June 4. Some good news The circumstances that led to the smoky chaos of 2023 were unique. Canada didn't just break its wildfire records that year, it obliterated them. Nearly 58,000 square miles of the nation burned - an area about the size of Illinois - in more than 6,500 wildfires coast-to-coast from April to October, according to revised numbers from the Canadian Forest Service. And weather patterns acted in a complex dance to redirect that smoke to the United States. "Not at the same time, but one weather pattern would be succeeded by another weather pattern that were responsible for transporting smoke across Canada and the United States," Romanic said. 2025 looks smoky, but not that as smoky So far this year, wildfires in Canada have burned nearly 7,685 square miles, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. While that's about four times the average, it's still well below the 11,766 square miles that were scorched as of this date in 2023, which remains the nation's worst wildfire season on record. Romanic said the summer forecast by Environment and Climate Change Canada showed continued hot and dry conditions throughout this summer, particularly in northern Ontario and the western provinces. "We expect a hotter summer than normal," he said. "Such an environment is likely to sustain an above-average fire season, though it may not reach the scale of 2023." What weather pushes Canadian smoke into the US? Some of the weather patterns that transport smoke from Canada to the United States include northwesterly winds behind cold fronts that pass over Canada and move into the United States, Romanic said. Also, high-pressure systems (ridges and anticyclones) over central and eastern North America can trap smoke close to the ground due to the large-scale subsidence (sinking) associated with them, he added. In addition, he said that at higher altitudes, if the smoke rises there, certain jet stream alignments can transport smoke particles from Canada to the United States. A tricky science As for what's going to happen with smoke this summer, Christy Climenhaga, a scientist from Environment and Climate Change Canada told USA TODAY June 5 that "smoke forecasting is a tricky science." She said it depends on a number of factors, including the location of both the source fires and the end location, how big the fires are, along with the weather patterns in place at the time. In 2023, a predominant large-scale jet-stream pattern featured a large ridge in the western United States and Canada, and a trough across the East. This allowed the fires to burn under hot, dry skies and the smoke from the fires to funnel into the eastern US. "It can get stuck in this persistent pattern for a while," she said. With a smoky summer forecast across Canada this year, this pattern could again spread smoke downstream into the U.S. throughout the summer. Contributing: Keith Matheny, Detroit Free Press

urn:contentItem:6GPW-DND3-RV4J-H3MT-00000-00Manhattan Is Back at the Center of the Restaurant Universe2025-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisGQ WORLDPg. 48Manhattan Is Back at the Center of the Restaurant UniverseBRETT MARTIN- with contributions by KRISTA SCHLUETER

In New York-and much of the country-COVID was a near extinction event for restaurants. But out of the ashes, an entirely fresh crop of new dining experiences has reasserted Manhattan as the place you have to be-and eat.

Eugene remm knows exactly when COVID-19 ended in New York City. It wasn't when the city "reopened," or when masks largely disappeared, or even when, seemingly by act of universal amnesia, everybody decided they were through talking about COVID-19.

"Totally unscientific, backed by no data whatsoever, my heart says that September 2024 was the time when the world became what the world is going to be," he said. We were sitting in a booth at The Corner Store, which Remm and his partners had opened that very month and which has been one of New York's buzziest restaurants ever since.

"The people who left New York came back; new people who wanted to be a part of New York came in," Remm said. "New York finally felt alive and vibrant. I don't know how else to say it: It just felt good. It just felt right."

There were facts to back up the vibes. Last fall was about the time that the last major physical reminder of the pandemic-the outdoor-dining structures of the early shutdown-began to disappear. These often hastily improvised constructions had both been a lifeline to the city's restaurants and an emblem of the surreality of urban plague life. (As the writer Jay Ruttenberg described it in his zine, The Lowbrow Reader: "One minute, a man was diligently pursuing partnership at Sullivan & Cromwell; the next, he was sitting in the middle of Ninth Avenue, eating udon noodles in a shed.") At the same time, workers were being called, or dragged, back to the office in numbers approaching pre-pandemic levels. Landlords who had been content to leave their storefronts vacant for years started to fill them with what the Times heralded as "a surge of new restaurants."

COVID was a restaurant cataclysm: A thousand NYC restaurants are estimated to have closed in the pandemic's first six months alone. But, five years on, the disaster turns out to have been a forest fire, rather than an asteroid. And fires, devastating as they may be, leave all kinds of creative regeneration in their wake: Pent-up nutrients are released back into the soil. Sunlight floods areas that haven't seen it for decades. Dormant seeds stir to life. Innumerable corners and cavities are suddenly open to be occupied.

That is what New York feels like right now, as though the death of one age ushered in the dawn of another. There's a sense of teeming-as though all manner of eclectic forms, some new, some revived, are finding their niche. Neglected neighborhoods are springing to life, pop-ups are finding their forever homes, new ideas are occupying old spaces like hermit crabs. A beloved East Village Ukrainian diner, Odessa, dies, only to birth the punk-vegetarian unicorn Superiority Burger in its place. On one stretch of Sixth Avenue, in the Village, I passed two reversals I never dreamed I'd see: In a shuttered chain drugstore, once the scourge of "authentic New York," there was a new Central Asian supermarket and hot bar while, down the street, the old Gray's Papaya, the iconic hot dog shop cruelly replaced in 2014 by a juice bar, had reverted to a slice shop-which is at least a step in the right direction.

As a lapsed new yorker, I wanted to see the shape of what was coming to life for myself; as someone who was born in Brooklyn and lived there for four decades, I took some perverse pleasure in limiting my explorations to the borough from which I sensed most of the energy coming: Manhattan.

I have been paying attention to the Brooklyn restaurant scene since it was nascent enough that my article on a Manhattan chef setting up shop in a Park Slope bar warranted the headline: You Want Pesto Aioli With That, Mack? One of the biggest ongoing stories of my career has been the diminished centrality of Manhattan in the dining cosmos. For decades, talent and energy have flowed outward: across the river to Brooklyn and Queens, and thence around the country, to innumerable cities, large and small. Compared to these, the aged bastion could seem staid and hidebound, prisoner to the ruthless demands of its own economies of real estate and attention, an overmanaged old forest with no room for unruly new growth.

But the past few years have brought a kind of turnabout. Restaurateur Kip Green told me that at her successful Brooklyn businesses, Margot and Montague Diner, the crowds have grown older and more conservative in their tastes. In 2018, when Green arrived in New York from South Carolina at 17 years old to attend culinary school, there was no question to which borough she would be headed. "There was so much more energy in Brooklyn," she said. "I very rarely went to Manhattan. Now it's kind of the opposite. It almost feels like everybody left Manhattan and now everybody's coming back, so there's fewer rules."

If you needed a symbol to sum all this up, last September offered that too: That month, the quintessential restaurateur of early-21st-century Brooklyn, Andrew Tarlow, opened his first restaurant in Manhattan. Borgo is a smooth, almost aggressively unquirky trattoria, located on East 27th Street, on the edge of Kips Bay, a neighborhood which may not be the almost literal wilderness of early 2000s Williamsburg, but is nevertheless way off the cool map. The shot of Tarlow's arrival there was followed, five months later, by the chaser of his announcement that he would close the 21-year-old Marlow & Sons, the restaurant that did as much as any to establish the Brooklyn aesthetic now found around the world. Tarlow downplayed the significance when we talked, insisting that each transaction was a separate matter of real-estate economics, but the resonance is real. Kip Green put it this way: "So long as Marlow & Sons was open, it felt like there was still space to do anything in Brooklyn." Now, that sense of infinite possibility felt foreclosed. (After we spoke, Green and her partner announced plans for their next restaurant, Cleo, located in, yes, Manhattan.)

"You're seeing people who were developing ideas throughout the pandemic and now have more confidence to open up," said Josey Stuart, one of three partners in Chinatown's Bridges, yet another zeitgeisty opening of September 2024. At the same time, says one of her partners, Nicolas Mouchel, wary landlords who may have been content sitting on properties are thinking again: "I think we're starting to see a lot more landlords and property developers understanding the value that a good restaurant brings to a building or their assets."

Bridges took over a space that had been a 47-year-old dim sum restaurant but whose dining room had been dark since March 2020. The restaurant, with walls clad in an industrial gray and an archway of glass blocks dividing the dining room from the bar, brings to mind the "downtown" of an earlier generation. (See: After Hours.) Chef Sam Lawrence's sharp-elbowed, technique-forward food, filled with surprisingly intense punches of sweetness and acidity, undercuts the notion that New Yorkers have become interested only in old comforts.

Then again, I'd been warned that, even more than usual in a city of 25,000 restaurants, the current scene was incoherent, that every piece of data could be met with two contradictory ones. Not long before my visit, I got a press release about a new "New York inspired restaurant." Aside from the weirdness of this being something somebody would open inNew York, there were the various things that could mean: a "neo-bistro," a high-end omakase, a caviar-drenched oligarch den, a boldly authentic Indian spot, a Greenmarket-inspired New American spot? (It was a Greenmarket-inspired New American spot.)

The frenetic activity trundles on despite all rumors of the outside world and its alleged instabilities. Any diner in America can tell you that going out to eat has become astonishingly expensive, with menu prices for even the most banal meal reading like random number generators. At the same time, chefs and restaurateurs say they're barely scraping by, margins pushed to the vanishing point by rising costs on the one hand and the limits of what the public will tolerate paying on the other. Listening to both sides, you might conclude that the entire project is untenable, that no restaurant anywhere could possibly survive and no diner could go there if it did.

Of course, the opposite is true. Across the country, there seems to be no end to either people willing to step up and try their hand at the restaurant business or customers lining up to love it. On both sides of the pass, we are a nation of restaurant junkies.

At Demo, one of a wave of food-focused wine bars that stretches back to the Lower East Side's Wildair (where its principals once worked), I sat over six admittedly delicious but nevertheless diminutive bites of cured Spanish mackerel with gribiche that cost $28 and eavesdropped on a chef pitching an investor on his new project. The chef spoke too quietly for me to hear the specifics, other than the sense that it would be expensive and took a lot of words to explain. The money man did not speak quietly; he wore a baseball cap and called the bartender "big guy" and the wine "natty." The chef had barely gotten through his spiel before his audience threw his arms open, needing to hear no more. "Well, you know what they say," he exclaimed. "Everybody's gotta eat!"

The last time i spent extended time in NYC, outdoor dining still lent the city the giddy vibe of a European street festival: New Amsterdam all over again. It was lovely, but also unsettling. Now, it felt like some of the city's jangled, pitiless, indifferent-to-mere-mortals energy was back. It was kind of thrilling. A couple of Martin Amis lines, from 1984's Money, ran through my head as I pedaled Citi Bikes up and down the island: "With money, double-dazzle New York is a crystal conservatory. Take money away, and you're naked and shielding your Johnson in a cataract of breaking glass." To love New York fully is to understand that's at least as much advertisement as warning.

If New Yorkers have a singular talent, it is for taking the empirically unpleasant and transforming it into a tribal point of pride. There is no greater example than what is required to eat out there: The lines! The impossibility of reservations! The prices! This is a city that is a prime hub for Dorsia, an exclusive reservation club unironically (or at least not ironically enough) named for the restaurant in American Psycho. (You cannot currently pay for a membership with crypto, according to the website's FAQ, but you'll be able to soon.) One friend I talked to told me that the price and hassle of dining had made him more risk averse, more likely to fall back on comfortable and reliable spots. Another said the opposite: If he and his wife were going to pay for a night out, they wanted fireworks.

No organization in New York City dining has provided more fireworks over the past decade than Major Food Group. MFG currently has dozens of properties in 13 cities, including Carbones in Vegas, Miami, and Riyadh-but they are first and foremost responsible for helping shape, for better and worse, the modern Manhattan dining experience.

One way has been leading the rise of the "dining group" to become the defining entity of the restaurant scene. The Bear notwithstanding, the heroicized chef is out, replaced by the highly curated, high-touch conglomeration. Longtime New York Times critic Pete Wells compares them to fashion houses, each purveying its own distinct package of vibes. He points out that they are perfectly matched to a generation of diners who may be skeptical of Great Men but were raised on the veneration of brands.

No group has been more successful in consistently and profitably replicating its own swaggering formula than MFG.

Its latest blockbuster is Torrisi, in the Puck Building, just below Houston Street. It's named for Rich Torrisi-a kind of companion piece to his partner Mario Carbone's namesake, the centerpiece of the MFG empire. The new place is Italian, too, but less bombastic and more innovative. This is in keeping with the chefs' Lennon-McCartney dynamic; when MFG opened two restaurants in the landmark Seagram Building, back in 2017, The Grill, helmed by Carbone, was a temple to New York normcore, while Torrisi's The Pool was a more ambitious seafood restaurant (that lasted only a few years). Together, the two were part of the great line-cook revolution that upended the New York dining map starting in the 2000s. More than that, they have always been singularly canny about what money wants-in particular, the allure of spending more and more of it.

The kitchen at Torrisi is as accomplished as you would expect from its Michelin star. It equally is attentive to detail on classics, like cellophane-thin slices of American and Italian ham draped over freshly fried zeppole, and stoner inspirations, like cavatelli with a ragù based on the filling of a Jamaican beef patty.

Likewise, the battalions of staff. Our server had a wondrous accent: Mike Francesa starring as a kid from Brooklyn in a World War II movie, while eating a bagel, nursing a pigeon, and telling a cabbie he was walking here. "The cucumbuhs are probably some of the best in New Yawk," he advised. As with the Jamaican patty pasta, it made one wonder: Was this genuine or a bit? Where does New York stop and "New York" begin? Impossible to say. But in any event, the man was right: The cucumbuhs were.

That night, I went to The Corner Store. In between, in an effort to burn off some cavatelli, I stopped in to the International Center for Photography for an exhibition of the great 20th-century photographer Weegee. The show included both his famous crime shots and less well-known later work shooting celebrities in Hollywood. It was titled "Society of the Spectacle," after the French philosopher Guy Debord's book by that name. A founder of the Marxist, avant-garde Situationist International organization, Debord decried a world in which all social relationships had become mediated by images and in which "all that was once directly lived has become mere representation." This was in 1967 and obviously nothing that somebody posting photos of food on Instagram (or opening a New York-inspired restaurant in New York) could possibly know anything about.

I saw plenty of spectacle at The Corner Store but no real crimes. The bar was packed with beauty and humming with anxiety, a flamboyance of flamingos with long, slender necks peering hopefully this way and that. Once you penetrated the dining room, it was cozy and insulated, more Rat Pack clubby than oontz-oontz.

In a corner booth, under a framed photo of Thomas Keller at the stove, Eugene Remm held up his phone to show me the number of Resy notification requests for open reservations that night. It was 1,244. He said the line outside on West Broadway for a handful of walk-in spots had begun forming at 3:30 p.m., an hour and a half before their 5 p.m. first seating

Remm is a New York nightlife veteran. He is the cofounder of Catch Hospitality Group, which has restaurants in Aspen, Miami Beach, and Las Vegas, among other locales. Catch LA, he told me, was particularly known for its entryway, which several years ago was voted "most Instagrammable walkway."

Catch is co-owned by Houston chain-restaurant billionaire, and Trump administration ambassador to Italy, Tilman Fertitta, who also recently bought the venerable Keens Steakhouse, in Midtown. The Corner Store opened on the site of one of Fertitta's properties, a Mexican spot called Dos Caminos on the corner of Houston and West Broadway, in SoHo. Soon after, Taylor Swift stopped in twice in three weeks. The lines have formed by 4 p.m. ever since.

The Mexican restaurant was famous for a lavish outdoor patio on Houston Street, but the night I was there the patio was closed off, tented over, and being used as a coat check. In what might be the greatest New York restaurant flex of all time, Remm confirmed that he hadn't opened it at all, and might never. He clearly understands the benefits of limited supply in the face of overwhelming demand. He said that in the context of his company, The Corner Store never really needed to make money. Rather, it was a proof of concept for future Catch Hospitality restaurants. The pre-Taylor business plan had the restaurant doing about 50 percent of the revenue it has turned out to bring in. "This was an art project," Remm said.

The Corner Store bills itself as "an upscale take on a classic American joint." That leaves a lot up to the interpretation of "upscale," "classic," and "American," but none as to which joint is in question. For at least 10 years now, Hillstone has been a hipster shibboleth-the sneakily excellent, preternaturally consistent chain restaurant that knowing foodies like to go to when they are exhausted with knowing foodieism. I suppose it was only a matter of time before the antidote to the scene became the scene itself. You see its supposedly uncomplicated pleasures in the popularity of 4 Charles Prime Rib, in the puckered pepperoni cups served with ranch dressing at Bad Roman, and in every shrimp cocktail on the menu at seemingly every restaurant in New York.

There are at least four direct references to the Hillstone menu on The Corner Store's. They include the spinach-artichoke dip and a French dip sandwich, which is made with Wagyu and comes with a crystal bowl of au jus. (My brother, who is a doctor, always orders an extra cup of au jus when visiting Hillstone, for sipping.) One Hillstone devotee I know complained that the Wagyu in The Corner Store's French dip made it too rich, but it's hard to be too mad about it. Maybe most happily, The Corner Store is as devoted to the martini as Hillstone is-serving its several varieties alongside a sidecar with a little booster, set in a bowl of crushed ice.

It irritates Remm to hear The Corner Store described as a "clubstaurant," and to have its culinary offerings-which include a plate of five-cheese pizza rolls-dismissed as a sign that the swing toward comfort food has gone too far.

"I think the people who have controlled what is considered a good restaurant are no longer in control. It goes against their brand to appreciate a big company that's been around a long time, that's successful, and that isn't, like, two cousins opening a restaurant in Brooklyn," he said. "We have 1,400 people on our waiting list, and that's how I know we're doing a good job."

Walking up first avenue, in the East Village, I came upon what at first seemed like an empty storefront. It was a Saw-like chamber, with one wall covered in mirrors, another of white-painted bricks, and a floor of scuffed, purple tiles. A purple awning out front read "SURPRISE SCOOP" and two touchscreens explained the deal: You paid $9.18 and, soon after, a small window in the back wall slid open and disembodied hands delivered a takeout container of ice cream. The scoop's flavor was the eponymous surprise, and not subject to appeal. Before completing your order, you had to check a box acknowledging that you accepted the inherent risks. On a mirrored wall was the legend: "THEY WILL LEARN TO LIKE IT."

On the one hand, I thought, walking on, this was one version of the perfect New York restaurant, circa 2025: low in overhead, high in potential virality, serving comfort with which only the most lactose intolerant could quarrel. On the other hand, "They will learn to like it" rang a bell so distant it might as well have been chiming on Mars.

There was a time when They Will Learn to Like It could have been the motto of every third restaurant in New York. Restaurants have always been acts of collaborative storytelling, narratives agreed upon between served and server. For a long stretch, these stories tended to be about restaurants as works of art, three-dimensional canvases on which chefs, newly elevated from the working to creative class, could paint their visions. In the wake of #MeToo and, later, Black Lives Matter, they became about restaurants as labor systems, communal hubs, and expressions of identity. It was COVID that lay bare what had of course been true all along-that above all restaurants are businesses, and precarious ones at that. In much the same way we inexplicably know what a Saturday Night Live cold open is, or can discuss the ad budgets of blockbuster movies, a diner today might be as familiar with food cost, average check size, and number of turns as they once were with sous vide techniques and heritage-breed chickens.

And so while chefs were once inclined to talk about their jobs in terms of activism, environmentalism, philosophy, science, fashion, celebrity-every possible role other than the sordid business of serving people food for money-they are now more likely to sound like Ed Szymanski, who, with his wife and partner, Patricia Howard, has methodically been putting his mark on the West Village.

Theirs has been a very modern trajectory. Heading into 2020, they intended to open a modern, nose-to-tail British restaurant. "Then the pandemic happened and nobody wanted our cheffy little plates," Szymanski explained. Instead, they organized a series of fish-and-chips pop-ups for Black Lives Matter in June 2020. That turned into a sensation, and then a permanent restaurant, the tiny Dame. In 2022, they returned to the gastropub idea, at the 65-seat Lord's, and this February, having found a prominent space on a corner of Sixth Avenue, they went big, opening a stately, plush, Riviera-soaked seafood restaurant, Crevette.

Crevette is only one entry in what has been a wave of seafood-centric restaurants across the island. They include Penny, a gleaming raw bar in the East Village that was a nominee for a James Beard Award for best new restaurant; the eccentric Smithereens, housed in a subterranean warren of rooms nearby that evokes Tokyo by way of Boston (it also has its own zine); and Salon Vert, a space-age, Breakfast-at-Tiffany's fantasy at the tip of Lower Manhattan, featuring Gregory Gourdet's Haitian-inflected food, set amidst the haute couture of Printemps. If the 2000s in American dining were all about meat-eating, and the 2010s about vegetables, the last five years have been all about seafood.

Before becoming a chef, Szymanski, who is 31, studied at the London School of Economics and worked in finance. This makes him perhaps the perfect chef-storyteller for this moment. To start, he rejects the idea that rapacious real estate is the biggest obstacle facing restaurants. Crevette's rent is $34,000 per month, but as high as that sounds, it amounts to less than 10 percent of the restaurant's revenue. "We would never sign up for a rent that we couldn't make in two days," he said. The far greater cost is labor, which has risen exponentially as front and back of house workers across the industry have demanded higher wages and more benefits.

Restaurants have an infinite number of ways to spend money (rent, utilities, trash pickup, insurance, linens, credit card fees, food cost, maintenance) and only one real way to make it, into which every cost needs to be factored. New Yorkers may have grown more sophisticated in understanding the value of ingredients, and have certainly grown inured to high prices, but even they can have trouble wrapping their heads around the bigger picture.

"If you broke down every cost and put a spreadsheet in front of a guest and said, 'This is what you're paying for,' they'd be like, 'I don't want to pay for that. I'll pay for the food,' " said Szymanski. "It's like, the customer pays for everything. How do you think this exists?"

Above all, he said, the key to a viable restaurant is to always be running at full capacity. "When I look at restaurants that fail, it's almost always not because they're not making enough money, it's that they're not full enough for the size of the restaurant," he said. "You hear people opening restaurants and saying, 'We're going to do three turns a night and we're going to do $200 a head.' They need to take a hard look in the mirror. Maybe they can fill their restaurant on a Friday and Saturday night. If you're not busy on Friday and Saturday night, you're going out of business real quick. What matters is if you're busy Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday. Those are the days where you either make money or you struggle." If you've wondered where all the lunch services have gone, or why it sometimes seems it would be easier to find a shot of unicorn milk than a restaurant open on Tuesday night, this is your answer.

I've spent most of my life trying to shed my New York provincialism. Emerging from Le Veau d'Or-into the Upper East Side of all places-I felt the stirring of its long-buried twin: New York chauvinism. It felt good.

Underlying all of this is the economic concept of perfect competition, in which endless demand and a relatively low barrier of entry means that, at least in theory, pretty much anybody can play the game. Szymanski maintains that New York's restaurant scene is just such a market.

"If you want to open a restaurant, you need a couple of hundred grand, and there are a lot of people in New York with a couple of hundred grand. So, say you open a great fish-and-chips restaurant. You're making loads of profit and I can see you're doing that. Because there's no barrier to entry, I can open a fish-and-chips restaurant next door, steal your cook, pay them more than you're paying them, and start to take your profits," he said cheerily. "You will be forced to compete with me, until none of us are making money."

Was it an accident that the restaurants I've thought about the most since this last visit to New York both featured three-course, prix fixe menus? I don't think so.

The prix fixe frees the diner from the tyranny of the tasting menu, but also, less obviously, from the tyranny of meal authorship. Until it was lifted, I'm not sure I had registered the decades-long stress we've all been under trying to piece together a coherent meal. The guesswork, the negotiations, the server's dubious recommendation of number of courses, the forensic analysis of leading and kerning: Is that extra space on the menu a demarcation between apps and main courses or just a printing error?

All of that is wiped away with a prix fixe, while much of what chefs love about tasting menus remains, primarily the ability to more tightly control what they'll serve in a given night. It also releases them from the pressure of luxury ingredients and tireless creativity the tasting menu genre has come to require. A win for all.

If the They Will Learn to Like It era had an avatar, it was David Chang's restaurants, which once seemed to own New York outright: Momofuku Noodle Bar, which opened in 2004, Momofuku Ssäm Bar, which followed a few years later, and, eventually, the multicourse tasting menu Momofuku Ko, which moved to a newly constructed space near First and Bowery in 2014. COVID spelled an end to this chapter, with the closing of Ko and Ssäm Bar, along with various other Momofuku properties in New York and abroad. But Kabawa, which opened earlier this year in the old Ko space, along with its more casual sibling, Bar Kabawa, are enough to make you believe that Momofuku had to die in order for Momofuku to live.

I used to think of Momofuku as the "House of No"-no substitutions, no allergies accommodated, no seat backs, no reservations, no bread (this was still a thing), none of the niceties or deference that diners of previous generations had come to expect. So, it was notable to find Kabawa so clearly establishing itself as a House of Yes. From its website FAQ (to which nearly every answer is affirmative) to the florid tie-dyed aprons on its servers and the warm greeting they extend at the door, this is a restaurant that takes as a starting point that it should function as a place of refuge. Led by longtime Momofuku chef Paul Carmichael, it is also among the most exciting entries in a growing list of restaurants exploring the cuisines of Africa and the Caribbean.

"Our MO here is to provide people with some sort of relief from New York through the lens of Caribbean hospitality," said Carmichael, who is from Barbados. "I want someone to walk in the door, take a breath, and be like, 'Feels different in here.' "

If there was one piece of architecture that represented the height of the tasting-menu era, it was the hermetic capsule of the rectangular counter, with an open kitchen at its center, at which all diners face inward like penitents at an altar. At Kabawa, the Ko counter remains (along with a stack of Lucky Peach issues, left untouched on a shelf), but somehow the feng shui has shifted. Carmichael is charismatic and omnipresent, with his wry grin and Medusa's fount of locs, but he doesn't demand your rapt attention. You lean back in your chair. You look around. You turn and talk to your companion. Miracles never cease.

That is not to say that the food does not warrant contemplation. Kabawa both takes its pan-Caribbean bona fides seriously and is willing to toss them to the wind in service of deliciousness. Two dishes haunt me weeks later: One is among the fried patties served in Bar Kabawa, filled with short rib, abalone, and bone marrow, its laminated dough etched with whorls like a fingerprint or an aerial photo of a dry lake bottom. The other is roasted goat, pulled into chunks and reassembled into a perfect cube and covered with a sauce that glowed with habanero peppers and dried scallop; the shoulder meat is kept in big enough chunks that you get the carnivorous pleasure that would come from ripping it off the bone yourself, a luxury akin to receiving a cold lobster broken down and reassembled in its own shell.

In fact, exactly such a lobster is available at Le Veau d'Or, the Upper East Side French gem resuscitated last year by Lee Hanson and Riad Nasr.

Between them, Hanson and Nasr unassumingly represent a pocket history of Manhattan dining: from Le Cirque (where Hanson worked under the legendary Sirio Maccioni); to Restaurant Daniel (where the two met and bonded over a love of hockey); on to the downtown-defining Balthazar, Pastis, Schiller's Liquor Bar, and Minetta Tavern (all of which they opened alongside Keith McNally); and finally to their own expanding empire. Multiple strands of their résumé converge and culminate in Le Veau d'Or's wood-paneled dining room: the stubborn Frenchness, which they helped usher back into fashion at Frenchette; the reclaiming of uptown as a center of culinary energy that began at Le Rock, their restaurant in Rockefeller Center; the seemingly magical reanimation of a classic space, oft-imitated after Minetta Tavern but rarely achieved. (They also own Frenchette Bakery, both the standalone bread-and-pastry shop and a restaurant by that name at the Whitney Museum, and recently announced plans for a new café at the historic Cherry Lane Theatre.) There had been several years of wandering in the wilderness following their split with McNally, with moments at which it seemed that the modern food world may have passed them by, which has made their charge back to dominance all the more triumphant. This year, they won the James Beard Award for outstanding restaurateur.

Nasr, who is no hippie, once told me that he thought there were certain crossroads and corners in the world that were energetically charged, nodes of human transit on an invisible grid, and that it was no accident that these became the sites of gathering places like great restaurants. By the evidence of Le Veau d'Or, 129 East 60th Street is such a place.

I've known both Nasr and Hanson for almost 20 years, and will happily admit to being in the tank for their sensibility, though I'd like to think that my love of their restaurants comes from the same wellspring as our friendship, rather than as a result of it. You could gloss over the food at Le Veau d'Or-a little omelet, a perfectly tempered slab of pâté en croûte, chicken with tarragon, lamb with spring beans-as standard French. But it is also quietly personal. In the appetizer of littleneck clams surrounded by fat chipolata sausages, an import from Frenchette, I can't help but think of the seafood tower the chefs and I shared at L'Avant Comptoir de la Mer, in Paris. In thick slices of the nutmeg-scented pork sausage called sabodet, served on a bed of lentils, I see Nasr and myself in the garage of Daniel Boulud's parents' farm outside Lyon, watching Monsieur Boulud extract his own gnarled version from an ancient steel pressure cooker. Throughout, you feel the primal appeal to appetites you find in Montreal, where Nasr grew up. Above all, Le Veau d'Or's menu is deeply New York-threading a needle between the classical era of uptown French dining and the modern one of downtown bistros: Lutèce meets Balthazar but squarely in 2025.

I've spent most of my life trying to shed my New York provincialism. Emerging from Le Veau d'Or-into the Upper East Side, of all places-I felt the stirring of its long-buried twin: New York chauvinism. It felt good. I don't need to catalog for you the elements of 1980s New York that are back and are catastrophic. If it happens to be that New York is once again the capital of the restaurant world, too, well, can't we just have that (and a Mets championship)?

If there was one moment that symbolized the death of the old order brought about by COVID, it was Gabrielle Hamilton's elegy for her tiny, beloved First Street restaurant, Prune, printed in The New York Times Magazine in April 2020. Already great during its two decades of life, Prune has achieved mythological status in death, becoming the very apotheosis of the independent chef-driven restaurant-which is to say, precisely the kind of restaurant that everybody agrees can no longer be opened in Manhattan.

So, what was I doing in a tiny, homey restaurant, on a gritty but hip street, eating a veteran woman chef's idiosyncratic but instantly embraceable cuisine, served by a tight, almost entirely female staff? This was Sunn's, in Dimes Square, landing place for Sunny Lee's long-running Korean pop-up. If Prune was small, Sunn's is minuscule. The kitchen, such as it is, is a narrow passageway housing an induction pad and a single burner. You loom self-consciously over it while waiting for the bathroom, itself so small that a cut-out had to be made in the back wall to accommodate a toilet. Somehow, Lee and her sous chef, Agnes Kim, utilize this space to turn out cascades of precise, welcoming food. This includes Lee's famed banchan (the multitude of small plates that accompany a Korean meal), which scramble up and down the ladder of texture, fermentation, and funk, to larger dishes like plump dumplings and deceptively rich and warming soups. Lee followed a familiar path from fine dining, through a stint as a private chef, and then into pop-ups, in venues from cold-water warehouses to apartment living rooms. She appears to have made no enemies along the way; she may be the most beloved chef in New York.

Sunn's still seems unlikely at first glance. Controlling the cost of staff is crucial, Lee told me when we spoke a week after my dinner. That day happened to be the first she would work a shift without Kim, who had been summoned to jury duty, since they had opened months earlier. "The only way she gets out of work is to do her civic duty," Lee said. A nightly waiting list that rivals The Corner Store's doesn't hurt, and neither does partaking in at least some of the benefits of a group. Sunn's lives in what was most recently the private dining area for a wine bar owned by her partner, Grant Reynolds, and the rent is low enough that Lee preferred not to disclose it on the record. (Suffice to say, it would make you angry.)

Every New York restaurateur-like every New Yorker-has a different answer to the central difficulty of living and thriving in the city, and this is Lee's. As Gabrielle Hamilton herself once told me: "You can talk all you want about your delicious food, your good ideas, your excellent cheffing, your disciplined management style, taking care of your staff, and adapting to and ignoring trendsæ. The bottom line is, how are you going to pay your fucking rent? What's your deal? What's your lease? And why did you agree to it in the first place?"

As for her deal, Prune remains shuttered, but not entirely idle. It is reportedly rentable for private affairs when Hamilton sees fit. And that, as ever, might be the purest expression of New York dining of them all.

BRETT MARTINis aGQcorrespondent.

urn:contentItem:6G00-R8N3-S2CJ-K3S0-00000-00Canadian wildfire smoke is back again. How bad will it get?2025-06-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:03:50ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWS & CANADA NEWSCanadian wildfire smoke is back again. How bad will it get?Doyle Rice, USA TODAY

In June 2023, a surreal glowing orange haze descended on New York City and across other East Coast locations as winds concentrated and redirected smoke from Canada wildfires. The smoke eventually lessened, but continued causing widespread unhealthy air quality in the United States throughout the spring and summer.

There are signs that this summer could bring a similar problem, as June 2025 brings hazy skies and air quality concerns in some areas.

The bad news: Smoke will likely be an ongoing health hazard across North America for the next few months.

"Communities across both Canada and the United States should stay informed about air quality advisories and be prepared for potential health impacts related to smoke exposure," atmospheric scientist Djordje Romanic of McGill University told USA TODAY in an e-mail June 4.

Some good news

The circumstances that led to the smoky chaos of 2023 were unique.

Canada didn't just break its wildfire records that year, it obliterated them. Nearly 58,000 square miles of the nation burned – an area about the size of Illinois – in more than 6,500 wildfires coast-to-coast from April to October, according to revised numbers from the Canadian Forest Service.

And weather patterns acted in a complex dance to redirect that smoke to the United States.

"Not at the same time, but one weather pattern would be succeeded by another weather pattern that were responsible for transporting smoke across Canada and the United States," Romanic said.

2025 looks smoky, but not that as smoky

So far this year, wildfires in Canada have burned nearly 7,685 square miles, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. While that's about four times the average, it's still well below the 11,766 square miles that were scorched as of this date in 2023, which remains the nation's worst wildfire season on record.

Romanic said the summer forecast by Environment and Climate Change Canada showed continued hot and dry conditions throughout this summer, particularly in northern Ontario and the western provinces. "We expect a hotter summer than normal," he said.

"Such an environment is likely to sustain an above-average fire season, though it may not reach the scale of 2023."

What weather pushes Canadian smoke into the US?

Some of the weather patterns that transport smoke from Canada to the United States include northwesterly winds behind cold fronts that pass over Canada and move into the United States, Romanic said.

Also, high-pressure systems (ridges and anticyclones) over central and eastern North America can trap smoke close to the ground because of the large-scale subsidence (sinking) associated with them, he added.

In addition, he said that at higher altitudes, if the smoke rises there, certain jet stream alignments can transport smoke particles from Canada to the United States.

A tricky science

As for what's going to happen with smoke this summer, Christy Climenhaga, a scientist from Environment and Climate Change Canada told USA TODAY June 5 that "smoke forecasting is a tricky science." She said it depends on a number of factors, including the location of both the source fires and the end location, how big the fires are, along with the weather patterns in place at the time.

In 2023, a predominant large-scale jet-stream pattern featured a large ridge in the western United States and Canada, and a trough across the East. This allowed the fires to burn under hot, dry skies and the smoke from the fires to funnel into the eastern United States.

"It can get stuck in this persistent pattern for a while," she said. With a smoky summer forecast across Canada this year, this pattern could again spread smoke downstream into the United States throughout the summer.

Contributing: Keith Matheny, Detroit Free Press

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Canadian wildfire smoke is back again. How bad will it get?
